Tetapi dia akan menyembah Tuhan Maha Pencipta, Yang menentukan hidup dan mati makhluk-Nya. Dia-lah yang memberi kesenangan dan kesusahan, kemanfaatan dan kemudaratan, menurut hikmah dan inayah-Nya, bukan tuhan seperti yang mereka sembah itu.

Dengan perbandingan itu maka bertambah jelaslah kebenaran agama yang dibawa Rasul saw dan kesesatan keyakinan kaum musyrikin. Kemudian Nabi Muhammad saw mengatakan kepada kaum musyrikin Arab bahwa dia diperintahkan supaya menjadi orang yang beriman. Allah telah menjanjikan kepada orang-orang yang beriman keselamatan dari azab, kemenangan atas musuh-musuh mereka dan kekuasaan di bumi.
text.105: Dalam ayat ini diterangkan bahwa Nabi Muhammad saw diperintahkan agar menghadapkan wajahnya dan seluruh dirinya kepada Allah, memfokuskan perhatian pada tugas-tugas agama dan mengabdi kepada Tuhan semesta alam. Sebab jika dia memberikan perhatian kepada selain Allah, maka hal itu mengurangi kebulatan jiwanya dalam menghadap Tuhan dan pengabdian terhadap agamanya. Kepada Allah sajalah hendaknya tujuan segala pengabdiannya lahir dan batin. Janganlah dia termasuk orang yang mempersekutukan Allah dalam ibadah dengan dewa-dewa, jin-jin, roh-roh, atau patung-patung seperti halnya penyembah-penyembah berhala. Larangan Allah terhadap Rasul ini dimaksudkan untuk mendorong dan merangsang Rasul saw untuk tetap menjauhi sifat-sifat syirik.
text.106: Allah menjelaskan larangan-Nya kepada Nabi saw agar jangan berdoa dan beribadah kepada selain Allah, Sebab selain Allah, tidak ada yang dapat memberi manfaat dan mudarat, atau memberi kesenangan dan kesusahan baik di dunia maupun di akhirat. Sekiranya Rasul berbuat demikian, maka dia termasuk dalam orang-orang yang menganiaya diri sendiri. Tiada kedurhakaan yang lebih besar dari syirik karena orang yang berbuat syirik mengembalikan urusan yang dihadapi manusia kepada selain Allah. Maka kembalilah kepada Allah. Panjatkanlah doa kepada Allah semata karena doa termasuk ibadah yang besar, bahkan otak ibadah.
text.107:
Kemudian Allah dalam ayat ini menegaskan keesaan-Nya dalam memelihara hamba-Nya. Hanya Dialah yang kuasa menghilangkan kesulitan hidup atau kemudaratan yang sedang menimpa hamba-Nya, baik kesulitan karena kekurangan harta ataupun karena terganggunya kesehatan dan perlakuan yang tidak adil dari orang lain. Segala kesulitan yang menimpa seseorang itu tentu ada sebabnya. Sebab-sebab itu diciptakan Allah sebagai ujian bagi manusia, apakah mereka benar-benar berserah diri kepada Allah atau tidak, dan mereka berada di bawah pengawasan-Nya. 

Manusia berkat pengalamannya yang lama dan luas dapat mengetahui sebagian sebab-sebab itu. Misalnya dalam soal kesehatan, menurut pengalaman manusia, bakteri tertentu yang menghinggapi tubuh manusia menjadi sebab bagi penyakit tertentu pula. Karena itu manusia menjaga dirinya dari bakteri tersebut dan bila dia sudah tercemar oleh bakteri tersebut sehingga sakit, dia akan berusaha mengobati penyakitnya sampai sembuh. Namun demikian, kesembuhannya bukan merupakan satu kepastian sebagai akibat berobat tersebut, tapi kesembuhan hanya dengan izin Allah. Demikian pula dalam bidang kehidupan manusia lainnya, seperti bidang sosial, ekonomi dan politik. Bilamana mereka mengalami kesulitan tentu ada sebab-sebabnya dan sebab-sebab itu berada dalam lingkungan mereka sendiri. 

Kewajiban manusia adalah mencari sebab sambil berdoa kepada Allah dengan sepenuh hati serta tawakal kepada-Nya. Sesudah menyebutkan tentang kesulitan hidup yang menimpa manusia, Allah menyebutkan pula tentang kenikmatan dan kesenangan yang dialami manusia. Mengenai kesenangan dan kelapangan hidup ini, Allah menyatakan bahwa jika Dia berkehendak dengan iradat-Nya melimpahkan kenikmatan kepada manusia, maka tak seorangpun yang dapat menghambatnya. Kebahagiaan dan kesenangan itu adalah karunia-Nya kepada hamba-Nya dan menurut iradat-Nya. Apa yang dikehendaki-Nya pasti terjadi, dan Allah tidak terikat kepada suatu sebab dalam memberikan kesenangan dan kebaikan. Karunia Allah atas hamba-Nya berdasarkan keluasan rahmat-Nya.

Allah Maha Pengampun, mengampuni segala dosa orang-orang yang bertobat, dan dosa orang kafir yang kemudian beriman kepada-Nya sebelum ajal tiba. Allah Maha Pengasih, mengasihi orang-orang beriman dan Dia tidak menyiksanya bila dia bertobat dari dosanya. Pengampunan dan kasih sayang-Nya meliputi seluruh umat manusia. Karena rahmat-Nya itu pula, maka tidak semua kejahatan di dunia ini dijatuhi siksaan tetapi menundanya sampai waktu tertentu.

Firman Allah:

Dan sekiranya Allah menghukum manusia disebabkan apa yang telah mereka perbuat, niscaya Dia tidak akan menyisakan satu pun makhluk bergerak yang bernyawa di bumi ini, tetapi Dia menangguhkan (hukuman)nya, sampai waktu yang sudah ditentukan. Nanti apabila ajal mereka tiba, maka Allah Maha Melihat (keadaan) hamba-hamba-Nya (Fathir/35: 45)
text.108: Allah menyuruh Rasul-Nya untuk mengatakan kepada orang-orang kafir sesudah disampaikan kepada mereka bukti-bukti keesaan Allah dan kerasulannya, bahwa kebenaran dari Allah yakni Al-Qur'an yang mendasari agama Islam, telah datang ke hadapan mereka, diturunkan kepada salah seorang di antara mereka sendiri. Dalam Al-Qur'an itu terdapat penjelasan-penjelasan dan uraian-uraian tentang rasul-rasul zaman dahulu dan dakwah mereka kepada kaumnya. Namun, kaum musyrikin Arab tidak mengetahui riwayat rasul-rasul itu, atau riwayat itu sudah diubah atau diputarbalikkan. Dalam Al-Qur'an terkandung pedoman-pedoman hidup bagi manusia untuk memperoleh kesejahteraan duniawi dan kebahagiaan akhirat. Maka barang siapa mengikuti pedoman itu dalam kehidupannya dengan penuh keimanan, manfaatnya akan kembali kepada dirinya sendiri. Dia akan hidup bahagia di dunia dan akhirat. Demikian pula sebaliknya, barang siapa yang sesat, tidak mempergunakan kebenaran itu (Al-Qur'an) sebagai pedoman hidup, dan tidak mengindahkan tanda-tanda kekuasaan Allah pada dirinya dan pada alam semesta ini, maka akibatnya kesengsaraan batin di dunia dan di akhirat. Nabi Muhammad saw wajib menyampaikan kebenaran itu kepada manusia. Keputusan terakhir berada pada diri manusia itu sendiri, apakah dia menjadikan Al-Quran itu sebagai pegangan hidup atau berpaling darinya. Beliau bukanlah wakil Tuhan di dunia ini untuk menentukan nasib manusia dan tidak kuasa memaksa seseorang memberi manfaat dan mudarat. Dia hanya pesuruh Allah yang menyampaikan perintah dari Tuhan Rabbul alamin.
text.109:
Allah dalam ayat ini memerintahkan Nabi Muhammad saw supaya dia tetap mengikuti apa yang diwahyukan kepadanya, dan bekerja menurut wahyu itu dan mengajarkannya kepada umat manusia, walaupun mereka tidak beriman kepadanya. Rasul saw juga diminta bersabar menghadapi segala macam gangguan dan penghinaan dalam menjalankan tugas tablig dan dakwah itu. Pada saatnya, keputusan Allah pasti akan datang sebagai hukuman terhadap para musuh agama itu, dan kemenangan atas Rasul dan umatnya sesuai dengan janji Allah kepada orang-orang mukmin. Allah adalah Hakim yang Maha Adil karena Dia memutuskan dengan alasan yang benar. Rasul saw menaati perintah-perintah ini dan dengan penuh kesabaran menunggu keputusan Allah. Ayat-ayat ini merupakan janji Allah yang menyenangkan Rasul dan orang-orang mukmin.

Saatnya akan datang di mana Rasul dan kaum mukmin memperoleh kemenangan dan kaum musyrikin mengalami kehancuran. Allah mewariskan dunia kepada orang-orang Islam, mereka menjadi penguasa-penguasa di bumi, dengan syarat mereka tetap menegakkan agamanya.

text.1:
See the meaning of "Alif Lam Ra" in the explanation about "mafatihus suwar" in the first volume.

Allah explains that the verses being read are verses of high value, neatly and firmly arranged, both in wording and meaning, containing guidance for those who want to follow them. From these verses are composed the surahs and the Al-Quran is compiled. In another of His statements, Allah explains the characteristics of the verses of the Al-Quran.

Alif Lam Ra. (This is) a Book whose verses are arranged precisely and then explained in detail from (One) Wise and Well-Acquainted. (Hud/11: 1)

From the arrangement of this verse, it is understood that Allah commands mankind to know, study, and remember the verses that serve as guidance, so that they can be understood and practiced.
text.2:
Sabab Nuzul: Ibn Abbas stated that when Allah sent Muhammad as a messenger, the disbelievers denied him, saying, "Allah is far more glorious than appointing a human being as His messenger, like Muhammad." Then this verse was revealed.

The disbelievers of Mecca in particular, and all disbelievers in general, were astonished and amazed, why the revelation was sent down to an ordinary human being like Muhammad, even to an orphan, and not to a prominent figure among them. Allah affirms with this verse that their astonishment is what is astonishing. Why should they be amazed that Allah has revealed the Quran to an ordinary human being? Only Allah knows best who is worthy and capable of conveying Allah's religion to all mankind. Wealth, power, position, and intelligence alone cannot necessarily be used as reasons to appoint someone as a prophet and messenger.

Indeed, their attitude towards the messenger sent by Allah is also found in previous people towards the messengers who were sent to them, as mentioned in Allah's words:

"Do you wonder that a reminder has come to you from your Lord through a man from among yourselves, that he may warn you and that you may fear Allah so you might receive mercy?" (al-Araf/7: 63)

Their attitude is due to the envy that has been hidden in their hearts; no matter what evidence is presented, they will not believe until Allah sends down punishment upon them. Allah says:

"And if We had made him an angel, We would have made him [appear as] a man, and We would have covered them with [the confusion] in which they are [already]. And already messengers before you were ridiculed, but those who mocked them were enveloped by that which they used to ridicule." (al-Anam/6: 9-10)

Allah explains the main tasks of a messenger, namely:

1.  To give warnings to mankind and explain to them about the Oneness of Allah, the existence of the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Judgment, the existence of punishment from Allah for all those who do not follow His religion, the provisions, commands, prohibitions of Allah, and so on.

2.  To give good news to those who believe, who follow the call of the Messenger, that they will receive a great reward from Allah, because they have done good and commendable deeds.

After the Arabs saw the immense influence of the Quran on the souls and hearts of the believers and their lives, they said that Muhammad was a magician, and the Quran was magic. They called the Quran magic because of its strong influence on the hearts of the believers, almost as great as magic, which can separate two people who were formerly brothers, between a person and his father, mother, wife, and children. Because of their great love for Allah and His Messenger, it was as if their love for their children, wives, and so on was diminished.

The believers are certain that the Quran is not magic, nor is it something that can be used for sorcery, but it is a collection of Allah's guidance, explaining matters related to faith, the principles of law, morals, good deeds that are pleasing to Allah, ways to cleanse the body and soul from all kinds of impurities, containing calls to the happiness of life in this world and the hereafter. Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah who conveys and teaches the Quran to mankind. The Quran is also a blessing and a miracle for Muhammad to strengthen his prophethood.

Because the Muslims greatly feel the benefits and guidance of the verses of the Quran for themselves, and the truth of everything mentioned in it. Therefore, they follow it wholeheartedly, following all the guidance that is very different from the guidance of polytheism, emulating the morals of the Prophet Muhammad which are different from the morals of their ancestors, following the customs of the Prophet which are different from the customs of their ancestors. They also love believers more than others, even if those others are their parents and so on. Thus, the disbelievers consider that the believers have been bewitched by Muhammad and they consider Muhammad to be a magician.
text.3:
In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who regulates the movement of planets and other celestial bodies, so that they do not collide with each other. He is also the One who created the earth and everything it contains, from the smallest to the largest, all created in six periods of time, the duration of which only Allah Himself knows. After creating the heavens and the earth, He Istawa (settled) upon the Arsy (Throne), and from this Arsy He regulates and manages all of His creation.

When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was asked about the Arsy, he said:

The Messenger of Allah said, "Allah existed before anything else, and there was nothing before Him. His Arsy was over the water, then He created the heavens and the earth, and wrote everything in the Lauh Mahfudh (Preserved Tablet)." (Narrated by al-Bukhari in Kitab at-Tauhid)

Furthermore, Allah explains another proof refuting the opinion of the disbelievers that the Quran is magic, which is that He owns and controls everything with unlimited power. He can do whatever He wills. No creature, even a messenger or an angel, can intercede except with His permission.

What is meant by "syafaat" (intercession) here is the help of angels, prophets, and righteous people to humans on the Day of Judgment to obtain relief or freedom from Allah's punishment if Allah commands or permits it.

This verse refutes the claim of the disbelievers that the idols they worship besides Allah can intercede for them on the Day of Judgment. This is emphasized by Allah's statement:

And how many angels there are in the heavens whose intercession is of no avail except after Allah has permitted [it] for whom He wills and approves. (an-Najm/53: 26)

The intercession that is most beneficial to a servant is the intercession given by the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to someone whose heart and soul acknowledge the oneness of Allah. Abu Hurairah asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) about this, and the Messenger of Allah replied:

"The happiest person who will receive my intercession on the Day of Judgment is the one who says: "La ilaha illallah" (There is no god but Allah) from a pure heart and soul." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah)

Allah emphasizes to the disbelievers, do they not remember and pay attention to these clear signs and proofs, that the One who created this universe is Allah Himself, He is the One who regulates all affairs from above His Arsy, and He is the One who gives intercession to whom He wills. That is the Lord who must be worshipped, there is no other god besides Him. Do not associate Him with anything, neither in the creation of the heavens and the earth, nor in His worship.

Even though the people of Jahiliyah (ignorance) acknowledge that Allah alone created this universe, without associating with anyone, they associate Allah with others in His worship. They worship idols alongside worshipping Allah.
text.4:
To Allah alone will all people return after death and after the annihilation of this transient world, not to anything else, such as idols worshipped, which are considered helpers for the disbelievers. That is Allah's promise to His creation. He will not break His promise in the slightest.

As proof that Allah will certainly fulfill His promise, He created the first creation. Allah's creation of mankind for the first time can be used as evidence that Allah is also able to create His creatures a second time and resurrect them. Repeating the creation of something is easier than creating something for the first time.

Allah says:

"And it is He who begins the creation; then He will repeat it, and that is easier for Him." (ar-Rum/30: 27)

So strong is the evidence presented by Allah regarding the Day of Resurrection, that He states that if there are still people who deny it, it means they have forgotten their own creation. Allah says:

"Does man not consider that We created him from a [mere] sperm-drop - then at once he is a clear adversary? And he presents for Us an example and forgets his [own] creation. He says, "Who will give life to bones while they are disintegrated?" (Yasin/36: 77-78)

To those who do not want to believe in the existence of the Day of Resurrection even though evidence has been presented to them, Allah threatens them with Hell, as depicted by the following verse:

"Then by your Lord, We will surely gather them and the devils; then We will bring them around Hell upon their knees." (Maryam/19: 68)

Allah explains the purpose of mankind being resurrected after death, which is to give them recompense for the deeds they have done in accordance with Allah's attributes of justice and generosity. Allah does not reduce in the slightest what they have done. This purpose is explained by Allah's words:

"And We place the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection, so no soul will be treated unjustly at all. And if there is [even] the weight of a mustard seed, We will bring it forth. And sufficient are We as accountant." (al-Anbiya/21: 47)

Allah giving just recompense does not mean that Allah will not increase the reward that He will give; in fact, He will multiply it, as mentioned in His words:

"So as for those who believed and did righteous deeds, He will give them in full their rewards and grant them extra from His bounty. But as for those who disdained and were arrogant, He will punish them with a painful punishment, and they will not find besides Allah any protector or helper." (an-Nisa/4: 173)

If we see many unjust actions committed by some people against others, and evil deeds outweighing good deeds in the world, and so on, then there must be a time in the future when justice can be established perfectly.

The disbelievers who deny the Oneness of Allah and the existence of the Day of Resurrection will receive a recompense commensurate with the evil they have done. Among them, they are given to drink boiling hot water that destroys their intestines. In addition, they will receive a painful punishment because of their disbelief.
text.5:
This verse explains that Allah created the heavens and the earth and is established on His Throne (Arsy). He is the One who made the sun shine and the moon illuminate. The sun, with its light, is a source of life, a source of heat and energy that can move Allah's creatures that He created. With light, humans can walk in the darkness of night and carry out activities at night.

This verse distinguishes between the light emitted by the sun and that reflected by the moon. That emitted by the sun is called "dhiya" (radiance), while that reflected by the moon is called "nur" (light). As explained in Allah's previous word:

And there He created the moon a light and made the sun a lamp? (Nuh/71: 16)

From these verses, it is understood that the sun emits light originating from itself, just as a lamp emits light from itself, namely from the fire that burns the lamp. It is different with the moon, whose light comes from the reflection of the sun's rays onto its surface, then that light is reflected back as light to the earth's surface.

The sun and moon are two celestial bodies that are often mentioned in the Quran. The word moon appears in 27 verses and the sun is mentioned in 33 verses. Often these two objects are mentioned together in one verse. A total of 17 verses mention the sun and moon in succession. Usually, verses that mention the sun and moon in succession are verses that explain the kauniyah (cosmic) aspects of these two celestial bodies. In 3 verses, these two celestial bodies are mentioned together with stars, other celestial bodies.

Verse 5 of Surah Yunus above is an example of a verse that mentions the sun and moon in succession. This verse indicates three important aspects of the creation of the sun and moon.

First, in this verse, Allah mentions the sun and moon with different names. Although these two celestial bodies both emit light to the earth, the designation of light from both is always mentioned differently. In this verse, the sun is called dhiya and the moon is called nur. This is to distinguish the nature of the light emitted by these two objects. Today, science has shown that sunlight comes from nuclear reactions that produce very high heat and bright light. Meanwhile, moonlight only comes from the reflection of sunlight reflected by the moon's surface to the earth. This different term shows that the Quran indeed comes from Allah the Creator, because at the time the Quran was revealed, human knowledge had not reached such an understanding.

In other verses, the sun is called siraj (lamp) and the moon is called munir (bright and sparkling).

Blessed is He who has placed in the sky great stars and placed therein a siraj (sun) and a moon giving light. (al-Furqan/25: 61)

And Allah created therein the moon as a light and made the sun a lamp. (Nuh/71: 16)

More emphatically, in another verse the sun is called siraj and wahhaj (blazing).

And We have built above you seven strong (heavens), and made a lamp [of] blazing intensity (the sun). (an-Naba/78: 12-13)

Second, Allah's affirmation that the sun and moon are always in a certain orbit (wa qaddarahu manazila). This orbit is subject to the law that Allah has made, namely the law of gravity which states that there is an attractive force between two objects that have mass. The magnitude of this attractive force is directly proportional to the mass of the two objects and inversely proportional to the distance between them.

It was Newton who formulated the law of gravity in the 18th century. Calculations using this law of gravity have successfully accurately calculated the orbit traveled by the moon when orbiting the earth, as well as the earth when orbiting the sun. This law of gravity is what Allah meant when He said in Surah al-Araf/7: 54: "... (He created) the sun, the moon, and the stars subject to His command..." The sun, moon, and stars are subject to Allah's provisions, namely the law of gravity that controls the movement of objects. In various other verses, it is often mentioned that Allah is the One who has subjected the moon and the sun to humans (See for example Surah ar-Rad/13: 2, Ibrahim/14: 33, an-Nahl/16: 12, Luqman/31: 29, Fathir/35: 13, az-Zumar/39: 5). What is meant is that Allah is the One who has determined that the sun and moon and stars are subject to the law of gravity that He has established.

Third, Allah's provision regarding the regular orbit of the moon and sun is intended so that humans know the calculation of years and the science of hisab (litalamu adad as-sinina walhisab). Can you imagine, if the moon and sun were not in a regular orbit, or in other words circulated randomly, how could we calculate how long a year or a month is? Glory be to Allah, the Most Merciful, who has determined everything for the convenience of mankind.

This is also explained by Allah's word:

Blessed is He who has placed in the sky constellations and placed therein a sun and a moon giving light. (al-Furqan/25: 61)

In their essence and usefulness, there are differences between sunlight and moonlight. Sunlight is harsher than moonlight. Sunlight consists of seven basic colors, although in its entirety it appears white, while moonlight is soft, and creates tranquility for those who see and feel it. Likewise, its usefulness. Sunlight, as mentioned above, is a source of life and livelihood, a source of motion, power and energy. While moonlight is a light at night.

There are countless uses and benefits of sunlight and moonlight for Allah's creatures in general, and for humans in particular. All of this can actually be used as evidence of the existence of Allah the One for people who want to use their minds and feelings.

Allah explains that He has determined the orbit of the moon and determined manzilah-manzilah (places) for its journey. Every night, the moon passes through a manzilah. From the first manzilah to the last manzilah takes between 29 or 30 nights or is called one month. In a month, the moon can only be seen for 27 or 28 nights, while on other nights the moon cannot be seen, as Allah says:

And the moon - We have determined for it phases, until it returns [appearing] like the old date stalk. (Yasin/36: 39)

The meaning of this verse is that the moon at the beginning of the month is small in the shape of a crescent, then after passing through the manzilah it becomes larger until it becomes full, after which it gradually becomes smaller, and becomes smaller looking like a curved stalk, finally disappearing and reappearing at the beginning of the month.

Allah says:

The sun and the moon [move] by precise calculation. (ar-Rahman/55: 5)

Allah created the moon and made it circulate along its orbit in its manzilah-manzilah so that humans can easily know the number of years, the calculation of time, the calculation of months, the determination of days, hours, seconds and so on, so that they can make plans for themselves, for their families, for society, for their religion and other plans related to their life and livelihood as members of society and as servants of Allah. Allah says:

And We have made the night and day two signs, and We erased the sign of the night and made the sign of the day visible that you might seek bounty from your Lord and that you might know the number of years and the account [of time]. And everything We have set forth in detail. (al-Isra/17: 12)

By knowing the calculation of years, time, days and so on, humans can determine the times of prayer, the time of fasting, the time of performing the hajj pilgrimage, the time of going to the rice fields, and so on.

Allah created the sun shining and the moon illuminating, which is beneficial for the life and livelihood of all creatures, based on reality, necessity, and having high wisdom. And Allah explains the signs of His power to people who want to use their minds correctly and to people who want to acknowledge reality and believe based on the evidence they have obtained. In other words, these signs of Allah's power and greatness will not benefit in the slightest those who do not want to seek the truth, whose hearts are filled with envy and fanaticism towards the beliefs they have embraced.
text.6:
In this verse, Allah explains another of His signs of power, namely the alternation of night and day, although this alternation, in the sense of the succession of night and day, is caused by the Earth's rotation around its axis. The difference in the length of night and day is due to the location of a place on Earth, which is caused by the Earth's axis being tilted twenty-three and a half degrees from its orbital path and the Earth's revolution around the sun.

In addition to the alternation of night and day, in this verse Allah also explains that among the signs of His power is that Allah created in the heavens and on earth a variety of things, such as liquids, solids, air, plants and animals, thunder, lightning, wind, all of which are evidence and signs of Allah's greatness and power, for those who are willing to be mindful of Him ( *taqwa*).
text.7:
These verses explain that the reason people do not believe in the meeting with Allah in the afterlife, where all deeds will be weighed justly, is because they love worldly life more and are willing to exchange the pleasure of life in the hereafter for the fleeting pleasure of life in this world. This is also because they are influenced by worldly delights, as are those who are negligent and do not heed the verses of the Qur'an, nor are willing to study, understand, and practice them; their place in the future will be Hell Jahannam.

Such a punishment is due to the sins they committed during their life in this world, and the reward is commensurate with their actions.

In this verse, two kinds of attitudes and actions of humans are mentioned that cause them to enter Hell, namely:

1.  Disbelief in the existence of life after death, because they have been influenced by worldly pleasures.

2.  Not heeding the verses of the Al-Quran.

Disbelief in the existence of life after death, to meet Allah, means disbelief in the justice of Allah and His love for His servants. Such people are usually those who think that everything they have obtained is solely due to their own efforts, and not as a mercy and favor from God; as if they are the ones who determine everything. Such traits can lead to atheism, which holds that God does not exist, and that humans alone create everything. This is in stark contrast to the main principle of Islamic Aqidah.

Likewise, not heeding the verses of the Al-Quran means not believing that the Al-Quran is the Book of Allah revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw, the last prophet, and also not believing that the book can be a guide for humans in navigating the ship of life in this world to achieve eternal life in the hereafter.

Belief in the existence of life after death, and that the Al-Quran is the Book of Allah revealed to Muhammad saw, are the main principles of Islamic teachings. Denying these two main teachings means denying Islamic teachings. That is why Allah threatens with severe sanctions in the form of the torment of Hell Jahannam against those who deny Him.
text.8:
These verses explain that the reason people do not believe in the meeting with Allah in the afterlife, where all deeds will be weighed justly, is because they love worldly life more and are willing to exchange the pleasure of life in the afterlife for the fleeting pleasure of life in this world. This is also because they are influenced by worldly pleasures, as are those who are negligent and do not heed the verses of the Qur'an, nor are willing to study, understand, and practice them; their place in the future will be Hell Jahannam.

Such a punishment is because of the sins they committed during their life in the world, and the reward is commensurate with their deeds.

In this verse, two kinds of attitudes and actions of humans are mentioned that cause them to enter Hell, namely:

1.  Not believing in life after death, because they have been influenced by worldly pleasures.

2.  Not heeding the verses of the Al-Quran.

Not believing in life after death, to meet Allah, means not believing in the justice of Allah, and His love for His servants. Such people are usually those who think that everything they have obtained is solely due to their own efforts, and not as a mercy and favor from God; as if they are the ones who determine everything. Such traits can lead to atheism, which holds that God does not exist, and that humans alone create everything. This is in stark contrast to the main principle of Islamic Aqidah.

Likewise, not heeding the verses of the Al-Quran means not believing that the Al-Quran is the Book of Allah revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw, the last prophet, and not believing that the book can be a guide for humans in navigating the ship of life in the world to achieve eternal life in the hereafter.

Belief in life after death, and that the Al-Quran is the Book of Allah revealed to Muhammad saw, are the main principles of Islamic teachings. Denying these two main teachings means denying Islamic teachings. That is why Allah threatens with severe sanctions in the form of the torment of Hell Jahannam against those who deny Him.
text.9:
In this verse, Allah explains the good recompense and reward that believers who do righteous deeds will receive in the Hereafter, which is that they will be given a noble place in the form of Paradise, full of delights.

Faith and righteous deeds are two things that are very closely related, intertwined and interconnected. There are many verses in the Al-Quran that explain the closeness of this relationship. Faith is in the form of conviction and belief in the existence of the One God, the Creator and Owner of the universe, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful to His servants. Because of His attributes of Most Compassionate and Most Merciful, He bestows guidance and direction upon mankind so that they, with that guidance, may live happily in this world and in the Hereafter. This guidance is acknowledged by believers as guidance from Allah, the manifestation of which is as mentioned and exemplified in the Al-Quran and the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (saw). Thus, the righteous deeds performed by a Muslim are a manifestation of his faith, or in other words, someone who has professed faith will certainly be inclined to do righteous deeds. It is impossible for someone who believes not to do them.

Faith and righteous deeds are the reason for humans to live happily in this world and to be rewarded by Allah with Paradise in the Hereafter. Thus, they have reached the highest level of spiritual life.
text.10:
This verse describes three parables of the lives of the believers in Paradise. From these three parables, a high level of spiritual life that they have achieved is depicted. The depictions are:

1. Their prayer, beginning with the words, "Subhanaka Allahumma."

2. Their greeting of respect is, "Salam."

3. The end of their prayer is, "Alhamdulillahi Rabbil Â'lamin."

Prayer is a supplication offered to the Most Great, wholeheartedly with respectful words, because of feeling the greatness of the place of asking. The acknowledgment of Allah's greatness is expressed with the words "subhanaka Allahumma" (Glory be to You, O Allah). This sentence gives the understanding that Allah is One, only He alone is entitled to be worshipped, who is entitled to be glorified. Every creature is obliged to devote themselves to Him forever, both in this world and in the Hereafter. Creatures like this are entitled to obtain eternal happiness and pleasure.

Their greeting of respect is "salam," which means to be prosperous and safe from what is disliked and unwanted. This greeting of respect has always been uttered by them during their life in the world.

In Surah al-Ahzab/33:44 it is explained that "salam" is also the greeting spoken by Allah to the believers when they first meet Allah in the Hereafter. Allah says:

Their greeting on the Day they meet Him will be, "Salam (peace)!" And He has prepared for them a generous reward. (al-Ahzab/33:44)

This greeting of respect is also spoken by the angels to them, when they first enter Paradise.

Allah says:

And those who feared their Lord will be led to Paradise in groups until, when they reach it while its gates have been opened, its keepers will say, "Peace be upon you; you have become pure; so enter it to abide eternally therein." (az-Zumar/39:73)

And in this greeting of respect is also spoken by fellow believers in Paradise. Allah says:

They will not hear therein ill speech but only [greetings of] peace. And they will have their provision therein morning and afternoon. (Maryam/19:62)

The height of the spiritual life achieved by the believers in Paradise will also be understood from every closing of prayer and request that they offer to Allah, namely "Alhamdulillahi Rabbil Â'lamin" (All praise is due to Allah, Lord of the Worlds). These words are also spoken by the believers when they first enter Paradise.

Allah says:

And they will say, "Praise to Allah, who has fulfilled His promise to us and made us inherit the earth [so] we may settle in Paradise wherever we will." And excellent is the reward of [righteous] workers. (az-Zumar/39:74)

And these words are also spoken by the angels when they are around the Throne (Arsy). Allah says:

And you will see the angels surrounding the Throne, exalting [Allah] with praise of their Lord. And judgment will be rendered among them in justice, and it will be said, "Praise to Allah, Lord of the worlds." (az-Zumar/39:75)

From this verse, it is understood that it is obligatory for every believer to purify his soul and cleanse himself. The way to purify the soul and cleanse oneself is by worshiping Allah, controlling desires and directing them to do good deeds and righteous deeds. It is not purifying oneself by using intermediaries, such as making intermediaries of people who are considered sacred and so on, or expecting intercession from them. In fact, such actions can lead to polytheism (shirk). Allah says:

Not [merely] by your wishful thinking, nor by the wishful thinking of the People of the Scripture. Whoever does a wrong will be recompensed for it, and he will not find besides Allah a protector or a helper. (an-Nisa/4:123)

These three kinds of parables of the high spiritual life obtained by the people of Paradise should always be accustomed to and practiced by the believers while they live in the world so that they may obtain eternal happiness as well.
text.11:
One of the characteristics and natures of humans is the desire for everything that will happen to them to be accelerated or hastened, whether it be punishment or harm, good or reward. Even though they already know that all of that happens by the will of Allah, according to His laws and according to His decrees and regulations. Allah says:

...They are only awaiting the way of the former peoples. But you will never find in the way of Allah any change, nor will you find in the way of Allah any alteration. (Fathir/35: 43)

And Allah says:

(Such has been) the practice of Allah already in the past. You will never find in the practice of Allah any change. (al-Fath/48: 23)

In other verses of the Al-Quran, the hasty nature that exists in humans is explained, as Allah says:

And man supplicates for evil as he supplicates for good, and man is ever hasty. (al-Isra/17: 11)

And Allah says:

Man was created of haste. I will show you My signs, so do not impatiently urge Me. (al-Anbiya/21: 37)

The hasty nature of wanting to obtain goodness and pleasure in humans is because of their desire to obtain benefits from something in a short time, even though they know that everything has a process. That process requires strong determination/intention, patience, and perseverance. It is impossible for them to achieve a pleasure, but they do not try to achieve it by following the conditions for achieving something.

It is different with the desire of humans to experience a torment, danger, or disaster. This desire arises because of their ignorance, disbelief, disobedience, and denial of the Prophet Muhammad saw, or because they want to mock something they do not want, or because of their anger and hatred towards something, and so on, as happens to people who are desperate in their lives, so they ask for death upon themselves. Likewise, the disbelievers who do not want something conveyed by the Messenger of Allah, then ask for proof by immediately bringing the torment that was promised to them.

Their desire and request are answered by Allah firmly through His word in this verse, which is that if Allah wanted to grant the prayers and requests of humans, to inflict torment upon them or a disaster, according to the requests they submitted solely because of ignorance or wanting to weaken the proofs of prophethood conveyed to them, as was once requested by the polytheists of Mecca, then Allah would immediately grant it and that is very easy for Allah.

This request is often submitted by the polytheists of Mecca to the Prophet Muhammad saw who conveyed the religion of Allah to them. They ask for things that are not appropriate to the Prophet, such as asking for the coming of torment upon them as was once brought upon the nations of old, asking for the coming of the Day of Judgment, and so on, as Allah says:

And they urge you to hasten the punishment before the good, while there have already occurred before them similar punishments. And indeed, your Lord is full of forgiveness for the people despite their wrongdoing, and indeed, your Lord is severe in punishment. (ar-Raad/13: 6)

And Allah says:

And they urge you to hasten the punishment. And if not for a specified term, punishment would have come to them. And it will surely come to them suddenly while they do not perceive. (al-Ankabut/29: 53)

Even the polytheists, because they greatly deny the Al-Qur'an, dare to pray that torment be hastened upon them if what Muhammad conveyed is true. Allah says:

And [remember] when they said, "O Allah, if this [Quran] is indeed the truth from You, then rain down upon us stones from the sky or bring us a painful punishment." (al-Anfal/8: 32)

The polytheists who deny the existence of the Day of Judgment, challenge the Messenger of Allah to hasten the coming of the Day of Judgment, as Allah says:

Those who do not believe in it are impatient for it; but those who believe are fearful of it and know that it is the truth. Unquestionably, those who dispute concerning the Hour are in extreme error. (asy-Syura/42: 18)

The purpose of the polytheists asking the Prophet Muhammad saw to bring about the promised punishment immediately is not only because they do not believe in him, but also to refute and weaken the arguments and proofs of prophethood, to mock the verses of the Al-Quran that were conveyed to them, and to say to the Prophet Muhammad saw that they greatly deny everything that he conveyed to them. Sometimes among them there are those who believe in the Prophet saw, but envy towards Muhammad and fanaticism towards the religion of their ancestors have caused them to continue to deny him.

From this verse, it is understood that Allah will not grant their prayers and requests, and does not want their destruction as has been experienced by past peoples, but Allah is Most Gracious, Most Merciful to them. Muhammad was sent as the last prophet and messenger to all mankind as a mercy to all the worlds. Therefore, Allah always gives them the opportunity to repent. If they remain in denial and disbelief until death, then Allah will punish them with a painful torment.

Allah will not bring torment upon them in the world as has been inflicted upon past peoples, because if Allah inflicted torment upon them, then they would all be destroyed, and that destruction would also befall the believers who live and reside among them, as Allah says:

And if Allah were to impose blame on the people for their wrongdoing, He would not have left upon it [i.e., the earth] any creature, but He defers them for a specified term. And when their term has come, they will not remain behind an hour, nor will they precede [it]. (an-Nahl/16: 61)
text.12:
In these verses, Allah explains another characteristic of mankind, which is that when they are afflicted with harm, calamity, or difficulty, they remember Allah and pray to Him, whether in a state of lying down, sitting, or standing, so that all that harm is averted and removed from them. Conversely, if the danger of suffering and difficulty has disappeared and they have enjoyed Allah's mercy, blessings, and bounty, then they gradually forget the giver of that mercy and bounty, even becoming disbelievers in Allah.

This verse shows the weaknesses of mankind when they receive trials from Allah, and also shows mankind's dependence on the mercy and bounty of the Lord, the Creator and Regulator of their lives. Therefore, those who believe should remember and not forget their Creator and Overseer, both in times of difficulty and danger, and in times of ease and happiness. All of this is a trial from the Lord to His servants to test the strength of their faith. Those who succeed in overcoming all the trials they experience, whether in the form of difficulty or pleasure, are the ones who deserve to attain eternal happiness in this world and in the hereafter.

Those who transgress and those who are misguided, like the polytheists of Mecca, are those whose hearts have been turned away by Satan. Satan has made them see good in the evil deeds they have done, so that when the danger has disappeared, they will return to misguidance and disobey the Lord.
text.13:
This verse, on the surface, is addressed to the disbelievers of Mecca who constantly mocked the Prophet Muhammad, but it also includes all of humanity who behave and act like those disbelievers of Mecca. Past communities were completely destroyed because of their injustice, disbelief, and rejection of the messengers and prophets whom Allah had sent to them. Whereas those messengers and prophets had laid out the path of truth, which if they had followed, would have led them to a place of complete happiness.

People of the past were destroyed by Allah because of their injustice, as mentioned in His saying:

"And those cities - We destroyed them when they wronged, and We appointed a term for their destruction." (al-Kahf/18: 59)

Allah affirms that those who are unjust and reject the truth will surely be afflicted with a very painful punishment. Allah says:

"And there is no city but that We will destroy it before the Day of Resurrection or punish it with a severe punishment. That has ever been in the Register inscribed." (al-Isra/17: 58)

There are two types of punishments that Allah has inflicted upon people of the past because of their rejection and injustice:

1. By annihilating all those who deny the messengers and commit injustice, as He did to the people of 'Ad, Thamud, the people of Noah, and so on.

2. Bringing punishment in the form of corruption, chaos in society, and so on, as Allah says:

"And how many a city which was unjust have We destroyed and produced after it another people." (al-Anbiya/21: 11)

Corruption and chaos in society occur because of the abundance of individuals who have become corrupt, excessive luxury, a fondness for a life of extravagance, following desires, moral decay, and so on, which results in the weak among them being under the control of the strong. However, if they deny the messenger who brings guidance to the straight path, they can no longer accept the teachings brought by the messengers, because they have become accustomed to being unjust, disbelieving, and living to prioritize worldly pleasures, so their faith can no longer be hoped for in the slightest, then Allah destroys and annihilates them.

Thus, Allah gives recompense to those who are unjust and commit sins. Sometimes Allah destroys them all at once, or brings punishment in the form of corruption and destruction in their society. This is a stern warning from Allah to the polytheists of Mecca who deny the Messenger of Allah.
text.14:
After the previous communities were destroyed, Allah replaced them with the community of Muhammad, the community that follows the religion of Islam, a religion that leads humanity to happiness in this world and the hereafter.

This verse is good news for the followers of the Prophet Muhammad who were under pressure and persecution from the polytheists of Mecca at that time. With this verse, their conviction in the truth of Islam increased, and they became even more confident that their struggle would succeed with victory.

This promise of Allah is also in accordance with His word:

Allah has promised those who have believed among you and done righteous deeds that He will surely grant them succession [to authority] upon the earth just as He granted it to those before them and that He will surely establish for them [therein] their religion which He has preferred for them and that He will surely substitute for them, after their fear, security, [for] they worship Me, not associating anything with Me. But whoever disbelieves after that - then those are the defiantly disobedient. (an-Nur/24: 55)

This verse is a reminder for Muslims to always be careful in determining what they will do and to always remember the tasks that Allah has given to humans as Khalifah (vicegerent) on earth.

Among the tasks of the Khalifah on earth is to uphold rights and justice, cleanse this world from impure acts, shirk, immorality, and to elevate the word of Allah on earth. Allah will observe and record all human actions in carrying out their duties, whether they are in accordance with what He has commanded or not. As He says:

And it is He who created the heavens and the earth in six days - and His Throne had been upon water - that He might test you as to which of you is best in deed. (Hud/11: 7)

In connection with this verse, Qatadah said, "Our Lord has done what is right. He made us Khalifah on earth, only to see our deeds, so show Allah your good deeds in the night and day."
text.15:
This verse explains the attitude of the polytheists when the Prophet Muhammad recited to them the verses of the Qur'an revealed to him, which possessed a high degree of linguistic beauty and profound content, demonstrating all kinds of truth based on strong reasons and evidence. They challenged the Messenger to bring a book other than the Qur'an for them, one that contained things that did not contradict the beliefs they had adopted, that did not criticize their gods and objects of worship, that did not contradict their customs, and that did not prohibit what they had made lawful.

With that request, they intended to refute the arguments presented by the Prophet Muhammad. They hoped that Muhammad would be willing to grant their request. If Muhammad granted their request, it would mean that they had been able to weaken the reasons justified by Muhammad himself. So Allah taught Muhammad to say to them that the Qur'an is from Allah, not from himself. If he changed and altered it, it would mean that the Qur'an was his own creation, not from Allah. However, the answer they received was contrary to their expectations, even containing a tone of threat and stern warning, stating that because of their extreme denial, they were no longer worthy of receiving the teachings of Allah, but rather the punishment of Allah is what they would receive. The Prophet stated that it was not appropriate to change or replace the verses of the Qur'an. The verses of the Qur'an are the words of Allah, not his words, therefore only Allah Himself has the right to change or alter them. He is only a messenger of Allah, therefore what he follows is only the revelation that Allah has sent down to him. He will not follow anything other than that. He is certain and believes that if he indulged his desires and the requests of the polytheists, it would mean that he had disobeyed Allah, had denied the words of Allah, denied the existence of the Day of Resurrection, and so on. Such actions are threatened by Allah with a severe punishment.
text.16:
In this verse, Allah teaches the answer that Prophet Muhammad should convey to the polytheists who deny the Qur'an, which is the command to tell those polytheists that if Allah willed, the Prophet would not recite it. The Prophet recited the Qur'an to them solely on the command and will of Allah. If Allah had not willed to convey the Qur'an to them, He would not have sent him to them, so the Qur'an, which contains guidance for the happiness of life in this world and the hereafter, would not have reached them. Allah says:

"We have certainly brought them a Book which We detailed with knowledge - as guidance and mercy for a people who believe." (al-Araf/7: 52)

This verse affirms that Allah has revealed the Qur'an to Prophet Muhammad, which contains guidance for the benefit of life in this world and the hereafter, and affirms that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah who conveys that guidance to mankind.

As proof of the truth of the revelation that has been conveyed, Allah commands the Prophet to say to the polytheists that he (Muhammad) has lived and associated with them for more than 40 years. They all know the Prophet's characteristics, nature, and personality, and they also know his morals, behavior, attitude, and fairness towards them all. During that time, they all knew that the Prophet had never read a single book, because he was illiterate, had never learned from anyone, and had never conveyed words of equal value to the verses of the Qur'an. Therefore, is it true that the Prophet is lying, as they suspect? Why do they all ask the Prophet to replace the verses of the Qur'an with others?

As is known, every messenger sent by Allah to his people was given various privileges by Allah before being appointed as a messenger, such as Musa a.s. (Moses) being given wisdom and knowledge when he was between 30 and 40 years old, when his mind was perfect, as Allah says:

"And when he reached maturity and was sound of judgment, We gave him wisdom and knowledge. And thus do We reward the doers of good." (al-Qashash/28: 14)

Similarly, Yusuf a.s. (Joseph) was given wisdom and knowledge by Allah when he reached adulthood, before being appointed as a messenger, (Yusuf/12: 22) such as the knowledge of interpreting dreams and so on.

Nabi Isa a.s. (Jesus) before being appointed as a messenger, as a child in the cradle was able to speak, was born without a father, was given the Book, and Wisdom. (Â'li Imran/3: 46, 47 and 48)

Prophet Muhammad was given privileges by Allah like the privileges that had been given to the previous prophets and messengers. He was also given another privilege, namely a privilege that was directly felt, believed, and known by all members of the Meccan society at that time. All the people of Mecca considered him to be an honest person who could truly be trusted, he was seen as a fair person in making decisions, not biased.

An example is his wisdom in giving a decision to the Quraysh tribes who asked him to determine who had the right to put the Hajar Aswad (Black Stone) back in its original place when the Kaaba was renovated. The Quraysh leaders cleaned and repaired the Kaaba, so they removed the Hajar Aswad from its place. After the Kaaba was cleaned and repaired, they wanted to put the Hajar Aswad back in its place. The tribal chiefs argued in determining who was most entitled to put the Hajar Aswad back in its place. Each tribal chief felt entitled, so there was debate and disagreement that almost led to bloodshed among them. Then one of them asked Muhammad to make a decision about who was more entitled to put the Hajar Aswad back. Whatever the Prophet's decision would be followed. The person's request was approved by the tribal chiefs, and Muhammad was also willing to fulfill their request. He opened his turban and placed the Hajar Aswad on it, then ordered each tribal chief to hold the edge of the turban and lift it together. After arriving at the place of the Hajar Aswad, he placed it in its original place. This decision was recognized by the tribal chiefs as a fair, accurate and wise decision.

The people of Mecca trusted him very much, because of that trust he was given the title "Al-Amin" (the trustworthy). Because of that trust, Khadijah entrusted her merchandise to him. Finally, Khadijah became his wife. He was recognized by the people of Mecca as a person of noble character, strong personality, respected and so on.

After he served as a messenger, he conveyed the verses of the Qur'an to them and invited them to enter the religion of Islam, suddenly they accused Muhammad of being a liar, a person who disturbed public order and a person who changed and damaged the beliefs and customs that they had inherited from their ancestors since ancient times. Because of their hatred for Muhammad, they no longer remembered their attitude and trust towards him. This is what Allah means by His words above which mean: "Indeed, I have lived among you a lifetime before this."
text.17:
This verse explains that the most unjust people in the sight of Allah are:

1. Those who fabricate lies against Allah, as the polytheists have done due to their denial, which was to ask the Messenger of Allah to exchange the verses of the Qur'an with other words that do not contradict their beliefs.

2. Those who deny the verses of Allah. This verse gives a warning that those who commit one of the most unjust acts are those who deserve the wrath of Allah and His punishment. They have committed sin, and they will not attain success through those actions. Therefore, believers should guard themselves from committing such acts.
text.18:
This verse explains the form of belief of the Jahiliyyah Arabs. They worshipped idols alongside worshipping Allah, because they believed that these statues and idols could benefit them just as they could harm them if they did something that could provoke their anger. However, if they were to think and truly realize that the statue is a lifeless object made by their own hands, they would know that these idols could not cause harm or benefit to anyone, and surely they would not worship them. The only One worthy of worship is the Almighty and the Creator.

The Arabs during the Jahiliyyah period adhered to various religions and beliefs, and had several ways of performing worship to their objects of worship. All these beliefs showed the conviction that there were many gods, not one. In other words, they associated partners with Allah. Among them were those who embraced Judaism, such as some of the inhabitants of Medina and some of the inhabitants of Yemen, and there were also those who embraced Christianity, such as the inhabitants of Ghassan and the inhabitants of Najran, as well as a group of the Aus and Khazraj tribes who lived in areas bordering Khaibar, Quraidhah, and Bani Nadhir.

Among them were also those who adhered to the Sabiin religion, namely the people before the Prophet Muhammad who knew of the existence of the One God, and believed in the influence of the stars.

Then Allah explains the attitude of the Arabs towards idols, some of whom said that they believed that idols could not bring harm or benefit, but they believed that these objects of worship would be intermediaries for them to seek intercession on their behalf with Allah, and that was the closest path. Therefore, they made vows, slaughtered sacrifices, and prayed to these objects of worship and mentioned their names. By doing so, they felt closer to Allah.

It was narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim from Ikrimah that Nadhar bin Haris said, "When the Day of Judgment comes, Lata and Uzza will intercede for me."

From the above explanation, it can be concluded that the essence of the belief of the Jahiliyyah Arabs was that even though they believed in the existence of the Almighty Creator, in the relationship between God and humans, they still needed an intermediary (wasilah) who would convey their requests to their Lord. Then Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to convey to those polytheists something that could prove their falsehood and something that could refute their words by saying, "Are you informing Allah of something He does not know, namely that there are intercessors in the heavens and on earth who can provide intercession as intermediaries between Allah and His creatures, even though if there were, Allah would certainly know it." There is nothing in the heavens and on earth that Allah does not know, the existence or non-existence of something is solely according to Allah's will, let alone intercession, which is only given solely with Allah's permission and only given to whom He wills.

Rasulullah saw himself is not able to bring benefit to himself, nor to ward off harm except with the permission of Allah, as Allah says:

Say, "I hold not for myself [the power of] benefit or harm, except what Allah has willed. And if I knew the unseen, I could have acquired much wealth, and no harm would have touched me. I am not except a warner and a bringer of good tidings to a people who believe." (al-Araf/7: 188)

The end of this verse explains the transcendence of Allah, the Lord of the universe, from partnership as said by those polytheists.

This verse also indicates that everything related to God can only be obtained through revelation conveyed to His Messenger, while everything is known to Allah, both hidden and manifest.
text.19:
What is meant by one community here is one creed, namely believing in Allah the One and Only, because humans since being born into the world have adhered to the belief in monotheism. Allah has taken testimony from humans, since they were brought forth from their loins, (see the tafsir of Surah al-Baqarah/2: 213 and al-Araf/7: 172) as their natural disposition (fitrah), as the Prophet Muhammad saw said:

Every child is born in a state of fitrah, then it is their parents who make them Jewish or Christian or Magian. (Narrated by Abi Yala, ath-Thabrani and al-Baihaqi from al-Aswad bin Sari)

In the beginning, humans lived simply, in unity, as if they were one family. However, after they multiplied, tribes and nations were formed that were different, both in terms of their interests and benefits. Because of their desires, they disagreed. Therefore, Allah sent to them messengers who conveyed Allah's guidance, to eliminate disputes and differences of opinion among them. The messengers brought books containing Allah's revelation. Then humans disagreed again about the books that Allah had revealed, so that enmity and fighting occurred among them.

Some commentators (mufasir) are of the opinion that what is meant by "mankind" in this verse is the Arabs. They were formerly followers of the religion brought by the Prophet Ibrahim, a religion that acknowledged the oneness of Allah. Then elements of shirk entered their beliefs, so that some of them worshipped idols alongside worshipping Allah and some still adhered to the religion of the Prophet Ibrahim. A dispute arose between the two groups.

If we pay attention to these two opinions, there is no fundamental difference, because the first opinion is general in nature, covering all humans in the world, while the second opinion is specific to the Arabs only, but it does not rule out the possibility of it applying to all humans.

With a very stern warning, stating that if it had not been decreed by Allah beforehand to give a fitting and just recompense in the Hereafter, then Allah would have immediately destroyed those who disagreed in this world. They bring division and hostility, especially since their disagreement is about the Book of Allah, which was actually revealed to eliminate disagreement.
text.20:
This verse explains the attitude of the polytheists towards the Prophet by saying why Muhammad was not given signs of his apostleship related to this nature, as were given to previous prophets, such as the hurricane of Prophet Noah, the splitting of the sea for Prophet Moses, and so on.

Their request and astonishment are depicted in another verse, as follows:

And they say, "What sort of messenger is this who eats food and walks in the marketplaces? Why has an angel not been sent down to him to be a warner with him, or [why is not] a treasure cast down upon him, or does he [not] have a garden from which he eats?" And the wrongdoers say, "You follow not but a man affected by magic." (al-Furqan/25: 7-8)

They also requested other proofs of prophethood, such as beautiful gardens where rivers flow, or punishment by dropping the sky, or a house of gold given to Muhammad. In another verse, Allah says:

And they say, "We will not believe you until you break open for us from the ground a spring, Or [until] you have a garden of date palms and grapes and make rivers gush forth within them in force [and abundance], Or you make the heaven fall upon us in fragments as you have claimed, or you bring Allah and the angels before [us] face to face, Or you have a house of gold or you ascend into the sky. And [even then], we will not believe in your ascension until you bring down to us a book we may read." (al-Isra/17: 90-93)

So Allah taught Prophet Muhammad the answer to the requests of the polytheists as mentioned in His word:

And nothing has prevented Us from sending signs except that the former peoples denied them. And We gave Thamud the she-camel as a visible sign, but they wronged her. And We send not the signs except as a warning. (al-Isra/17: 59)

Every messenger sent by Allah was given miracles to prove and strengthen his message, but the miracles given were different, adjusted to the circumstances and place of the people who would receive the message. In particular, Prophet Muhammad saw was given the miracle of the Al-Quran because that miracle was in accordance with the level of knowledge of the Arabs and humans who lived after him. It is narrated that Prophet Muhammad saw said:

There is no Prophet (sent by Allah) except that He gave him miracles by which people believed in him. What was given to me was nothing but revelation that Allah revealed to me. So I hope that I will be among those with the most followers on the Day of Resurrection. (Riwayat al-Bukhari, Muslim, and at-Tirmidzi from Abu Hurairah)

Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad saw to give a stern warning to the polytheists by saying to them that the unseen is under the power of Allah, only He possesses it, including the miracles they requested. If Allah wills to send them down to them, then He alone knows the time of their descent. Muhammad is only a messenger, whose duty is to convey the religion and the decree of Allah upon them, just as Muhammad is among those who await the coming of that decree.

In another verse, Allah says:

Say, "I am not the first of the messengers, nor do I know what will be done with me or with you. I follow not except what is revealed to me, and I am not but a clear warner." (al-Ahqaf/46: 9)

What Muhammad saw was waiting for and what they were waiting for is explained by Allah in verse 102 of this surah.
text.21:
This verse explains the characteristics of disbelievers in general and the characteristics of polytheists in particular. That when Allah grants them ease after hardship, or happiness after misery, they do not acknowledge that the ease and happiness come from Allah, so they are not grateful to Him.

When Allah's mercy comes to them in the form of rain sent down from the sky that causes plants to grow and livestock to thrive, they declare that it is thanks to their idols and objects of worship, or they say that the rain falls by chance, because the rainy season has arrived. If they are afflicted with hardship, and then the hardship disappears, they say that the hardship disappeared solely because they themselves are clever people who can eliminate difficulties and are among the lucky ones. Such a thing was done by Pharaoh and his people every time they received Allah's punishment and every time they were released from it. The same was done by the polytheists of Mecca towards the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his followers.

Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abdullah bin Masud that when the Quraysh hurt the Messenger to excess, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed to Allah that the polytheists be afflicted with a punishment in the form of a drought like the drought that occurred in the time of the Prophet Yusuf. So they were struck by a very severe drought, until they were forced to eat bones and carcasses. Because of the drought and very high heat, their vision became dizzy and smoky, as Allah described in Surah ad-Dukhan/44 verse 10. Then Abu Sufyan, the leader of the Quraysh, came to Muhammad (peace be upon him), he said, "O Muhammad, indeed you command us to maintain kinship ties, and indeed your people have perished, so ask Allah to release them from this difficulty." So the Messenger of Allah prayed to Allah, then the difficulty and disaster ended and rain fell. Apparently, not long after, they returned to deny the Messenger of Allah and oppose him.

Because of their attitude, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to convey a warning to those polytheists that Allah is swifter in punishment than their schemes, Allah has prepared a punishment that will be inflicted upon them, before they have time to arrange deceptive tactics to destroy Islam and the Muslims. All good and bad deeds will be recorded by the angels that Allah has assigned. There is not a single human action, whether small or large, that they do not write down. Then in the Hereafter, every human being will receive the reward for all his deeds. Bad deeds are rewarded with the torment of hell, while good deeds are rewarded with the pleasures of paradise.

This verse indicates that all human conversations are recorded by angels and the existence of angels is affirmed by this verse.
text.22:
In this verse, Allah demonstrates His ability, power, and grace to mankind, saying, "He is Allah who has given you (mankind) the ability to walk on land, sail the seas, and fly in the air by giving you the opportunity to use various means such as stars, ships, and so on. With these means of transportation, you can achieve your various desires and for enjoyment."

With the ability and capability that He has given, mankind is tested and tried by Allah, so that their character and nature become clear, which Allah illustrates as follows: with the ability that He has given, mankind builds a ship that can sail the vast ocean. When they are in the ship and it sails carrying them with the help of a good breeze and calm waves, they rejoice. Suddenly, a strong storm wind comes and waves crash from all directions, causing anxiety and fear in their hearts. They feel that they will no longer be able to see the sun rise the next day because of the violent waves. Therefore, they pray to Allah while humbling themselves with sincerity, regretting the actions they have done, so that Allah releases them from the mighty waves, they say, "O our Lord, if You release us from the disaster that will befall us, then we will surely be among those who are grateful for the blessings that You have given."
text.23:
After Allah released them from that calamity and they felt happy and all their worries disappeared, they forgot the All-Savior and Bestower of Grace. Indeed, they were disobedient to Him and returned to committing destruction on earth by perpetrating injustice and chaos among people.

Thus, Allah depicts the character and nature of humans. They remember and humble themselves to Allah when they are afflicted with hardship, and when that calamity has vanished, they forget and even return to disobeying Allah.

The character and nature described above demonstrate the weakness of humans. Therefore, humans should realize and be aware of that weakness. Let not that weakness lead them to a greater calamity. Arrogance and acts of injustice, even if they bring pleasure, are only temporary pleasures, lasting only during life in this world. Eternal pleasure and happiness are those brought about by obedience to Allah in all circumstances, whether in times of joy and sorrow, happiness and grief, loss and profit, and so on. Such pleasure and happiness will be felt throughout life in this world, and even more so in the Hereafter.
text.24:
This verse explains the nature of worldly life and an appropriate analogy considering its transience, like the disappearance of a hope that begins to arise in a person. The nature of the world is likened to rainwater that Allah sends down from the sky. With that water, various kinds of plants and vegetation grow, diverse in appearance and different in taste, becoming food for humans and animals. Then the earth's surface is covered by the beauty of the scenery of green trees, adorned with flowers and fruits of various colors. At that time, the hopes and aspirations of the person who owns the garden arise, hoping that the plants will bear fruit and can be harvested. In the midst of such hope, a disaster comes that destroys the plants and trees, so that the earth, adorned with trees of various colors, suddenly becomes flat and level as if it had never been grown on. At that moment, those hopes and aspirations vanish, just as worldly life and pleasures can also vanish instantly.

The transience of life in this world is affirmed by Allah's words:

"Do then the people of the towns feel secure against Our punishment coming upon them by night while they are asleep? Or do the people of the towns feel secure against Our punishment coming upon them in the forenoon while they are at play?" (al-Araf/7: 97-98)

Just as Allah has given an accurate and clear analogy in describing the state of worldly life and how humans are deceived by that life due to the influence of Satan and following their desires, so too is it clear and bright how Allah explains the essence of *tauhid* (Oneness of God), the fundamentals of religion, good character, and righteous deeds that must be done and obeyed. Only those who are willing to use their sound minds can understand the analogy and explanation. Many people are negligent and deny because they feel they are self-sufficient, capable, and powerful, so they forget the true purpose of life and existence.
text.25:
Allah calls the Muslims to tread the path that leads them to Darussalam, which is the eternal happiness they will feel in Paradise later. As guidance to that happy life, Allah has given guidance to those He wills, so that they may tread the straight path, which is the path that can lead them to that happy life. They are forbidden to imitate the deeds of the polytheists who prioritize worldly life. They are so fascinated by worldly life; they will not expect any other happiness than what they have already felt. Thus, they have chosen the wrong path because worldly life is very limited and its happiness is not eternal. That is why Allah invites the Muslims to follow the sharia and guidance brought by the Messenger, so that they can live happily in this world and the hereafter. Allah's guidance given to humans is a very subtle sign, which can be achieved by a person using his mind by observing the universe and its contents, as well as the laws that apply within it, so that in this way humans can achieve the ultimate truth.

In addition, Allah provides explanations about the law, both general and specific, namely the sharia law that regulates the relationship between creatures and the Creator, as well as the relationship between fellow creatures. Allah's laws that apply to humans are shown by Allah with His taufik. Those who attain His guidance are those who are given the ability to understand and implement it. This hidayah is given by Allah to humans according to His iradah.
text.26:
In this verse, Allah explains that for those who can understand guidance, benefit from it, and practice it, Allah will give rewards according to their deeds. Furthermore, to encourage them to be even more diligent in practicing it, Allah promises a reward ten times greater or even more than that. Allah says:

(That) He may recompense those who do evil with [the penalty of] what they have done and recompense those who do good with what is better. (an-Najm/53: 31)

Those who perform good deeds will receive a reward exceeding the reward they should have received. They will receive multiplied rewards.

They will receive additional rewards of inestimable value, namely, they will truly know Allah, the Most Glorious. This knowledge is the highest knowledge, because they truly know the Creator of the universe and affirm the occurrence of the Day of Judgment. They live happily, from their faces shines a radiant light, with no trace of gloom or sadness, because they do not feel disappointed in their strong faith and do not feel distressed.

Allah affirms that these are the people who are entitled to be inhabitants of Paradise. They will reside therein forever. There they will experience eternal happiness, because they will not feel bored or weary of the pleasures they experience, nor will they fear the diminution of those pleasures or being expelled from there.
text.27:
In this verse, Allah provides an explanation that those who spread evil, commit mischief on earth, and disobey and deny the verses of Allah revealed to His Messenger, will receive a balanced recompense. They will receive punishment from Allah commensurate with their deeds. Their faces will appear contorted because they suffer from the consequences of the shirk that has penetrated their bone marrow, the evil that has poisoned themselves, and their oppression of themselves. At that time, they will not be able to defend themselves, because they cannot protect themselves or prevent the disaster that will befall them. Such is the torment they feel with deep regret, as a result of worshipping idols that they consider as intermediaries, capable of conveying their prayers to Allah. That is the Day of Recompense where no one can help them except their good deeds.

Allah's word:

"(It will be) the Day when no person will have power (to do anything) for another, and the Decision, that Day, will be (wholly) with Allah." (al-Infithar/82: 19)

As a sign of their regret, their faces will appear as black as the darkness of night, without a single spark of lightning, the glimmer of a star, or a ray of moonlight. They truly regret the deeds they committed in the world. Their hopes are empty, because they cling to false beliefs and deny Allah's guidance.

Allah affirms that they will be inhabitants of Hell, eternally, and there is no possibility for them to escape because that is the place that is fitting for them.

Allah says:

"And some faces, that Day, will be contorted, Expecting that there will be inflicted upon them a great disaster." (al-Qiyamah/75: 24-25)

And Allah's word:

"And some faces, that Day, will be dust-stained, Overwhelmed with grimness. Those are the disbelieving wicked ones." (Abasa/80: 40-42)
text.28:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to pay attention to the polytheists, that at a time determined by Allah, He will gather all the idol worshippers without a single one being left behind, that is, at the time when all of humanity will have their affairs examined. At that time, Allah will speak to those who associate partners with Him, while they are silenced, unable to utter a single word due to confusion and fear. "Why are they no longer together with their partners in that place? So that until that time they will witness what will be applied to them and what decision is appropriate to give them, as a reward for their actions that truly violate Allah's prohibitions and contradict their own fitrah, which is that they have worshipped idols. They can no longer deny their actions, because the evidence is clear and even incriminating against them."

At that time, their partners will testify that they did not only worship those partners, but they also made their own desires and Satan as gods. They made those idols as tools for their own interests. Then Allah gives an explanation that they and their partners will be separated and each will be examined, they as the accused, while their partners become witnesses.
text.29: In this verse, Allah explains that the idols will give statements, while Allah is sufficient as a witness between the idols and their worshippers. At that time, the idols will disown them and say they know nothing about their actions. In principle, those who associate partners with Allah will be punished because they have committed a great sin. They have worshipped something that does not deserve to be worshipped, even though they understand that they and the idols they worship were created by Allah. Therefore, Allah is the one who deserves to be worshipped, because He is the Being who has the highest power over all His creatures and He also has the power to bring benefit and harm if He wills.
text.30:
Furthermore, Allah explains that on the Day of Gathering (Padang Mahsyar), all of humanity will be gathered to receive recompense for the deeds they have done.
