No one will be free from His punishment. Those who do good will receive their reward, and conversely, those who commit evil will receive their punishment. Then, their affairs will be returned to Allah because He is the most entitled to make decisions for them. At that time, what they hope for in terms of intercession (syafaat), and everything they consider capable of providing help, will be in vain. Nothing will fulfill their hopes, let alone save them from the punishment that will befall them. Allah says:

"(It will be) the Day when a person will not possess power at all for [another] person. And the decision, that Day, is [entirely] with Allah." (al-Infitar: 19)

Allah calls upon the Muslims to take the path that leads them to Darussalam, which is the eternal happiness they will feel in Paradise. As guidance to that happy life, Allah has given guidance to those He wills, so that they take the straight path, which is the path that can lead them to that happy life. They are forbidden to imitate the actions of the polytheists who prioritize worldly life. They are so fascinated by worldly life; they will not expect any other happiness than what they have already felt. Thus, they have chosen the wrong path because worldly life is very limited and its happiness is not eternal. That is why Allah invites the Muslims to follow the sharia and guidance brought by the Messenger, so that they can live happily in this world and in the hereafter. Allah's guidance given to humans is a very subtle sign, which can be achieved by a person using his mind by paying attention to the universe and its contents, as well as the laws that apply within it, so that in this way humans will be able to reach the ultimate truth.

In addition, Allah provides an explanation of the law, both general and specific, namely the sharia law that regulates the relationship between the creature and the Creator, as well as the relationship between fellow creatures. Allah's laws that apply to humans are shown by Allah with His taufik. The person who achieves His guidance (hidayah) is the one who is given the ability to understand and implement it. This hidayah is given by Allah to humans according to His iradah.
text.31:
Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to say to the people of Mecca who opposed his prophethood: "Who sends down sustenance from the sky, and who causes the various plants to grow on earth for humans and their livestock?"

This statement was intended to make the polytheists of Mecca realize themselves and remember that idols are completely incapable of sending down rain, and that only Allah sends down rain.

Furthermore, Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to ask them: "Who has the power to create ears as instruments of hearing and eyes as instruments of sight, so that with these two senses they can recognize the universe with its phenomena?" With ears, humans can hear the words of others, and through them, they can receive knowledge and gain experience. Similarly, with their sight, humans can see the beauty of nature and receive signals that can guide their thoughts to know who created the universe.

Without these two senses, humans cannot fully know the state of the world. These two senses are mentioned in these two verses because they are the tools for receiving knowledge, so that humans have a higher degree than animals. Because, although animals have hearing and sight, they are not given reason by Allah, so that animals cannot receive knowledge except for animal instincts.

If humans like to contemplate who created these two senses, they will certainly not hesitate, and even without thinking long, they can find the answer. If they find the answer, they will certainly be grateful for Allah's blessings and will believe with true faith by acknowledging that there is no god other than the All-Powerful One who created these senses.

Furthermore, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah to ask the polytheists: "Who has the power to give life and cause death, and who creates living things from dead things and creates dead things from living things?" This question was deliberately asked to raise their awareness that only Allah creates plants from the dead earth, after the earth is given life by Allah by sending down rain, Allah's word:

"Do you not see that Allah sends down rain from the sky and causes it to penetrate the earth as water springs, then He produces thereby crops of different colors?" (az-Zumar/39: 21)

The signs of life in each creature are different. The sign of life in plants is that they can continue to grow, develop, and enlarge, while the sign of life for animals is moving and breathing. Such signs of life are easily understood and accepted by the human mind.

But what are the signs of life from seeds, whether single or double cotyledon seeds, or spore plants, and what about life in ovum and sperm, both from animals and humans? This is a sign that is difficult for humans to imagine and analyze.

Therefore, Allah gives an easily understood example, namely, taking living things out of dead things and vice versa, how to take dead things out of living things to express Allah's power to create all dead or living things with His power.

If someone wants to examine the origin of seeds, spores, ovum, and sperm, and all kinds of origins of life, then they will come to the conclusion that the origin of life of creatures on earth comes from dead things. Of course, this opinion is contrary to the opinion of biologists who say that all living things will not arise except from living things. Indeed, this opinion seems correct if we look at the cycle of life of animals and plants, but if we look at the origin of the event, the opinion is not accurate.

Furthermore, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to ask: "Who controls all kinds of affairs of creatures on this earth?" The control is very amazing. All kinds of life are regulated by harmonious and balanced laws. So, for those who want to contemplate His laws, he will give answers to all these questions that the One who created everything is Allah, the Lord of all the worlds, and He is the One who manages and controls it.

Allah commanded the Prophet, peace be upon him, to say to the polytheists, why do they not protect themselves from straying? If they wanted to protect themselves, they would not fall into polytheism and become idol worshippers. These objects of worship other than Allah have no power whatsoever to bring harm or benefit to them.
text.32:
Then, this verse alludes to the polytheists of Mecca that the Being who possesses the attributes mentioned previously is Allah, the One who sustains them, He is the True Lord, the Living and the Giver of Life. And He is the only One worthy of worship. And Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to declare to them that there is no God who manages all affairs in this world except Allah.

Allah rebukes their actions and demands accountability for why they deviate from the true religion, which is the religion of monotheism, to something false, as if they are fleeing from Allah's guidance and seeking a misguided path, even though they know the proofs of the truth of Allah, the True Lord. If they have known the proofs of the existence of Allah, the Creator of the universe, then they should not worship other gods. Because if that happens, it means their confession differs from their actions, and what arises in their hearts does not match what they do.

For those who humble themselves to Allah, it means they have taken the right path and received His guidance, because they worship the True Lord. But those who worship gods other than Allah, they are the ones who are astray, because they worship gods who are not entitled to be worshipped, whom they consider as intermediaries. Everyone who worships gods other than Allah is a polytheist (mushrik) and wallows in falsehood and falls into the valley of misguidance.
text.33:
Allah gives a threat to the wicked, a threat that cannot be changed because they refuse to believe in the religion proclaimed by the Messenger, which is the religion of monotheism and abandoning the worship of idols.

Those who refuse to believe in the religion of monotheism do so not out of compulsion, but based on their own will and effort because they do not have a correct perspective that can free them from the shackles of polytheism. That is why their souls cannot be directed to a guide that can distinguish between truth and falsehood. They have sunk deeply into disbelief, while they themselves are too fanatical about the beliefs of their ancestors. Allah says:

Indeed, those upon whom the word of your Lord has been justified will not believe, even if every sign should come to them - until they see the painful punishment. (Yunus/10: 96-97)
text.34: Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to ask them if there was even one among the gods they worshipped besides Allah, such as idols, ancestral spirits, animals, planets, angels, and jinn, who had the power to create creatures, then bring them back to life after those creatures had died? Of course, they would not be able to answer. This is because they denied the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection, the day they would be brought back to life from the realm of the grave. After that, Allah provided the answer through His Messenger, that the One who has the power to initiate life is only Allah, and He is the One who has the power to initiate life or restore it to its original state. However, they still refused to accept the true religion, which is the religion of *tauhid* (monotheism), and preferred to worship idols and statues, which they did because of their own inclinations, not because they were forced.
text.35:
Furthermore, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to pose a question to them: could any of the deities they associated with Allah provide guidance to the right path, like the guidance received by His believing servants? Allah affirmed that it is Allah who provides guidance (hidayah) in the sense of *taufik* (divine enabling). Allah's word:

He (Moses) said, "Our Lord is He who gave to each thing its form and then guided [it]." (Taha/20:50)

After the polytheists were unable to provide an answer because none of them felt they had received guidance from the deities they associated with Allah, neither guidance to be accepted as a creature nor a religion they accepted as legal guidance, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to answer that it is Allah who gives guidance to the truth. This includes guidance given through messengers, guidance given through His books, guidance obtained by humans because they are commanded by Allah to contemplate and think about natural phenomena, and guidance given by Allah through the five senses.

Allah commanded the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to ask them, "Which is more worthy to be followed: He who guides to the truth or those idols that cannot guide at all, not even know themselves?" Why do they accept such a choice? If they would use their reason and intellect, they would surely choose He who guides them, namely Allah. Because other deities cannot provide any guidance.

Allah rebuked their actions by asking what had befallen them, that they made those idols intermediaries to convey their worship to Allah, even though those idols are not the creators, nor the providers of sustenance, nor the providers of guidance. So why do they make an unfair decision, namely considering those deities they associate with Allah as Gods worthy of worship, worthy of being asked for help without permission from the Creator? From this perspective, the error of the polytheists and the wrongness of their actions become apparent.
text.36:
Next, this verse presents several reasons that demonstrate the truth of the religion of monotheism (tauhid) and the error of the beliefs of the polytheists (mushrikin), namely the majority of them who associate partners with Allah with other gods, oppose the Messenger of Allah (saw), and deny the Day of Resurrection. Such assumptions are not true beliefs, but rather conjectures based on blind imitation (taklid buta) of their ancestors because they assume that what was good according to their ancestors is good for them, even though what their ancestors did was misguided. On the other hand, there is a small group of them who know that the religion brought by the Messenger of Allah (saw) is the true religion, and the idols they worship cannot give them any influence. However, because their hearts are polluted by polytheism, and their arrogant and denial attitude towards the prophethood of Muhammad, as well as their fear of losing their leadership, they continue to blindly imitate their ancestors who wallow in polytheism.

Then Allah explains the true state of those who base their beliefs on conjecture, that indeed conjecture is of no use whatsoever in attaining the truth. These conjectures cannot be equated with certainty (yaqin), and certainty cannot occur unless it is based on something true, namely that which is firmly established, the truth of which cannot be doubted. At the end of the verse, Allah affirms that Allah is All-Knowing of whatever they do, whether actions based on beliefs whose truth is not yet certain, or deeds based on what is certainly true. He is the One who knows their deeds, and gives recompense according to their deeds.
text.37:
Allah explains that it is inappropriate and illogical for the Qur'an to be created by anyone other than Allah. And it is impossible for humans to create the Qur'an. The reason for this impossibility is that no one other than Allah is capable of creating something like the Qur'an. If anyone feels capable of creating it, then such an assumption is merely a dream that cannot be realized in the real world. This was once stated by the most disbelieving and hostile person towards the Prophet Muhammad saw, namely Abu Jahal, when commenting on Muhammad's honesty, "Muhammad has never lied to anyone, so is it possible that he would lie to Allah?"

So, if it is impossible for the Qur'an to be created by anyone other than Allah, then what can be believed is that the Qur'an is solely the word of Allah.

The Qur'an functions as a "verifier" of the previous scriptures, namely the scriptures revealed to Prophet Noah, Abraham, Moses, and Jesus (peace be upon them). The Qur'an contains the fundamental principles of religion that guide believers to Allah and the Hereafter, and to practice its contents in the best possible way.

The Qur'an was revealed to Muhammad saw not because the revelations that had been revealed to the previous prophets were untrue, but because mankind had forgotten most of the fundamental principles of their religion, and some even deliberately distorted their religion and mixed it with new traditions created by their leaders to corrupt the fundamental teachings of their religion.

These fundamental teachings of their religion had never been known to the Prophet Muhammad saw before he became a messenger, that is, before he received revelation from Allah.

It is said that the Qur'an is a verifier of the previous scriptures because the Qur'an carries fundamental teachings that correspond to the fundamental tenets of faith brought by Prophet Abraham. Also, it is because the arrival of the Prophet Muhammad saw, who received revelation from Allah, is in accordance with the indications contained in the previous scriptures, such as Allah's words:

"(Those) who follow the Messenger, the unlettered prophet, whom they find written in what they have of the Torah and the Gospel..." (al-Araf/7: 157)

The Qur'an functions as a "detailed explanation" of the contents of the scriptures revealed by Allah, namely the scriptures that contain the laws of Allah, and as guidance for all mankind, containing faith, sharia, exemplary models, advice, and social affairs. The Qur'an contains guidance and there is no part that can be doubted. The Qur'an comes from the One Who creates, and if the Qur'an were not the word of Allah, then surely confusion and many errors would be found in it.
text.38:
Allah shifts the conversation to the people of Jahiliyyah who denied the prophethood of Muhammad saw and claimed that the Qur'an was Muhammad's creation. Facing these accusations from the people of Jahiliyyah, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah saw to refute their accusations by saying that if their words were true, then they should produce a surah similar to a surah in the Qur'an, in terms of its appeal, its guidance of knowledge, its style of language, and its structure. As a challenge to them, Allah instructed the Prophet Muhammad saw to tell them to invite whomever they deemed capable besides Allah, to prove what they were saying.

Allah's word:

Say, "If mankind and jinn gathered in order to produce the like of this Qur'an, they could not produce the like of it, even if they were to each other assistants." (al-Isra/17: 88)
text.39:
Allah reveals that the polytheists were unable to answer Allah's challenge to create something similar to the Qur'an. Allah explains the true state of the polytheists: after hearing the verses recited by Muhammad, they immediately denied them, even though they had not first considered their content or understood the issue. This attitude was because they were hostile to Muhammad, who brought a new belief different from the beliefs of their ancestors.

Then, Allah compares the attitude of those polytheists with the attitude of the polytheists who lived in times before them. Because there is a similarity between them, namely, the polytheists of Mecca denied the verses received by Muhammad saw, while the polytheists from past peoples denied their messengers, both denying the revelation received by the prophets before investigating its truth carefully before understanding its explanation.

What is meant by explanation here is the reality that they must face as a result of denying the verses revealed to Muhammad saw, such as the reality that they or peoples in the past have received, as a result of their denial of the revelation they received. The reality they experienced was Allah's punishment that they felt in the world before they felt a heavier punishment in the Hereafter.

At the end of the verse, Allah explains that this is indeed the fate of those who deny the true messengers and prophets. This fate will certainly befall the polytheists of Mecca if they remain adamant in denying Allah's revelations. Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad saw and his followers to pay attention to how the end of the lives of people who oppress themselves because they dare to oppose and deny Allah's messengers.

Allah says:

"So We seized each of them for their sin; against some of them We sent a storm of stones, some were overtaken by a [mighty] blast, some We caused the earth to swallow, and some We drowned. And Allah would never have wronged them, but they were wronging themselves." (al-Ankabut/29: 40)
text.40:
Allah explains to the Messenger of Allah and his followers that the condition of the polytheists who deny the verses of the Qur'an will be divided into two groups. One group truly believes in the Qur'an with strong conviction, and the other group does not believe in it and continuously remains in disbelief. However, they will not be directly punished in this world like the fate experienced by the people before Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

At the end of the verse, it is explained that Allah knows best about those who cause corruption on earth, because they associate partners with Allah, wrong themselves, and oppose the law of Allah. This is because their fitrah (natural disposition) has been corrupted. They are the ones who will receive a painful torment.
text.41:
Allah provides clarification: if the polytheists continue to deny Muhammad saw, then Allah commands him to say to them that the Prophet Muhammad saw is obligated to continue his task, which is to continue the tasks of his prophethood, as a conveyer of Allah's commands whose truth is clear, commands containing warnings and promises, as well as guidance for worship along with the fundamental benefits that serve as guidelines for worldly life. The Prophet Muhammad saw is not commanded to judge them if they continue to maintain their attitude of denying the Qur'an and associating partners with Allah. Allah says:

"Say, "Each one acts according to his disposition. But your Lord is most knowing of who is best guided in way." (al-Isra/17: 84)

They disassociate themselves (are not responsible) for what the Prophet Muhammad saw does, and the Prophet Muhammad is not responsible for what they do. Meaning, Allah will not punish someone for the mistakes of another. Allah says:

Say, "You will not be asked about what we committed, nor will we be asked about what you do." (Saba/34: 25)

Say, "If I have invented it, then upon me is [the consequence of] my crime; and I am disassociated from what [crimes] you commit." (Hud/11: 35)

And His saying again:

And if they disobey you, then say, "Indeed, I am disassociated from what you are doing." (asy-Syuara/26: 216)
text.42:
Allah explains to the Prophet Muhammad and his followers that among those who deny the verses of Allah, there is a group of people who listen secretly when the Qur'an is recited. They pay attention to the essential points of religion contained within it, but they do not intend to listen with sincerity of heart, because at the time of listening they do not want to use their minds to pay attention to the content of the Qur'an, nor do they want to think about its meaning and purpose, so they cannot understand the true objective.

They want to listen because they are attracted to the beautiful structure of the Qur'an's language and are amazed to hear its beauty, like someone who is attracted to the chirping of birds in the trees; they can only enjoy the beauty but cannot understand the meaning contained in the chirping. Allah says:

"There does not come to them a new reminder from their Lord except that they listen to it while they are at play." (al-Anbiya/21: 2)

And His saying:

"And among them are those who listen to you, but We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And if they should see every sign, they will not believe in it. Even when they come to you arguing with you, those who disbelieve say, "This is not but legends of the former peoples." (al-Anam/6: 25)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that the Prophet Muhammad saw will not be able to make them hear and understand what they hear, because they have lost the benefit of the sense of hearing in the truest sense. They are not good listeners, because a good listener is someone who can think about and understand and implement the meaning and purpose of what he hears. Moreover, because they will never try to understand, they will not be able to benefit from what they hear and will not be able to understand the guidance contained within it.
text.43:
After that, Allah explains that among those who deny the verses of Allah, there is also a group of people who genuinely observe the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, when he recites the Qur'an. However, their attention is only superficial, merely observing the movement of the Prophet's tongue as he pronounces the words and their arrangement. It is not a pure attention that can understand and contemplate the meaning contained within the words arranged in the sentences. That is why the light of faith cannot shine in their hearts because it is covered by the stains of polytheism (shirk). They cannot see the signs of truth and guidance contained in the Qur'an. Yet, this inner vision is what distinguishes humans from animals. With that attention, humans should be able to understand and contemplate what they see, because Allah likens them to the blind.

At the end of the verse, Allah affirms that the Prophet Muhammad, as a messenger, is unable to make them see the signs of truth found in the verses of the Qur'an. Because they are indeed incapable of sensing the signs of truth in His verses, especially since they have no intention of using their inner senses to understand the content of the Qur'anic verses, ever.
text.44: Then Allah emphasized to the Muslims that He would not wrong His servants, nor would He diminish their senses and all the tools that humans possess to obtain guidance, so that they may reach the truth and be able to follow that guidance in order to achieve everything that is beneficial for them, as long as humans themselves are willing to use their senses in the best way. If the opposite happens, they are the ones who wrong themselves. Because they are given eyes and ears, but do not want to understand Allah's guidance, it means they are the ones who wrong themselves. Because they do not want to hear, and are given hearts but do not want to understand, then it is fitting that they are punished because they wrong themselves. Allah has sent messengers to guide them to a happy life in this world and the hereafter, but they do not want to listen and do not want to obey them, so if they go astray in this world and in the hereafter are sentenced to severe punishment, then those who wrong them are none other than themselves.
text.45:
Allah commands His Messenger to warn the polytheists that Allah will inflict punishment upon them on the Day of Judgment, when they are gathered in the Plain of Gathering (Padang Mahsyar) after being resurrected from their graves. They will be examined on that day and given retribution commensurate with their deeds. On that day, they will be able to compare how long they had to endure compared to the fleeting nature of worldly life. At that moment, they will feel regret for being deceived by the temporary life and pleasures of the world, forgetting the afterlife, which is eternal life. At that moment, they will experience prolonged regret and receive punishment. Allah says:

On the Day they see that which they are promised, (it will be) as though they had not remained (in the world) except an hour of a day. [This is] notification. And will [any] be destroyed except the defiantly disobedient people? (al-Ahqaf/46: 35)

And the word of Allah:

And the Day the Hour appears the criminals will swear they had not remained [in their graves] but an hour. Thus were they ever deluded. (ar-Rum/30: 55)

Allah explains that the polytheists feel at a loss because they cannot experience eternal happiness, because they do not believe with true faith, nor do they perform good deeds that can elevate them into noble beings worthy of receiving Allah's pleasure, so that they are entitled to enter Paradise. They also deny the belief that those who are pleased by Allah can meet with Allah. That is why Allah emphasizes at the end of the verse that they are among those who are not guided, because they have made the wrong choice, namely prioritizing the fleeting life of this world over the eternal life of the Hereafter, which contains unparalleled pleasures.
text.46:
Furthermore, the existence of Allah's promised punishment for the polytheists is affirmed, namely the punishment that will be inflicted upon them in this world and in the Hereafter. The punishment that will be inflicted upon them will be shown to the Messenger, in whole or in part, whether during the Messenger's lifetime or after his death. This depends solely on Allah's will. The meaning of the verse is that the Messenger of Allah (saw) will not know all the punishment that will be inflicted upon them, but only a portion of it, namely the punishment that has been inflicted upon them in this world, such as the granting of the Prophet's prayer during the Battle of Badr, which was the heavy rain that benefited the Muslims and harmed the polytheists, so that the Muslims achieved a glorious victory. Also, like the total defeat of the polytheists at the Fath Makkah, so that their power was completely destroyed. Even so, their affairs will be returned to Allah, because on the Day of Judgment, Allah will show Prophet Muhammad (saw) the entirety of the torment they will feel.

Then Allah will give a reward commensurate with the deeds they have done, and nothing can hinder the recompense and punishment that they will feel and experience. Allah says:

"So be patient, [O Muhammad]. Indeed, the promise of Allah is truth. And whether We show you some of what We have promised them or We take you in death, to Us they will be returned." (Gafir/40: 77)

And Allah says:

"Or [whether] We show you that [punishment] with which We have threatened them. Indeed, We are fully capable over them." (az-Zukhruf/43: 42)
text.47: This verse explains that Allah has sent a messenger to every people, at the time when that people needed him. The purpose of sending the messengers was to provide various guidelines that they were obligated to follow, such as the fundamental principles of *aqidah* and all righteous deeds that would save them from punishment on the Day of Judgment. When those messengers had come to them and had conveyed to them the guidance that they needed to know regarding religious matters, then they should not have made excuses to reject and oppose it. On the Day of Judgment, Allah will also give a decision about what they should feel with the utmost justice, and they will not be wronged in the slightest. That is the recompense that is commensurate with the deeds they committed, therefore they deserve to be subjected to a severe punishment.
text.48:
This verse explains that they will ask the Messenger of Allah and his followers about when the promise that has been pledged to them will occur. The question is a mocking question to the Messenger of Allah and his followers, as if in their judgment the promise of Allah will not happen. The promise of Allah that was asked of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his followers is the threat of Allah that will befall them, whether it be punishment in this world or punishment in the Hereafter.

Allah says:

...Until, when they see that which they are promised - whether punishment or the Hour - they will come to know who is weaker in position and less in soldiers. (Maryam/19: 75)

And His saying:

Say, [O Muhammad], "I do not know whether what you are promised is near or whether my Lord will grant for it a [long] period." (al-Jinn/72: 25)
text.49:
Allah taught the Messenger of Allah (saw) the answer he should give them by commanding him to say that he had no power to bring harm or benefit to himself. This is because the Messenger of Allah is only a messenger of Allah who has no power to hasten or delay the coming of the punishment promised by Allah to them, just as he cannot delay the coming of Allah's help promised by Allah to the Muslims. However, the coming of benefits and harms inflicted upon humans is solely at the will of Allah. This means that if Allah wills something to happen, it has nothing to do with the will of His Messenger, because the will belongs solely to Allah who maintains the universe. The Messenger's task is only to convey Allah's will, not to create it. If the Messenger of Allah knows about unseen matters, it is only because he knows them from Allah's revelation alone.

Allah's word:

"Say, "I hold not for myself [the power of] benefit or harm, except what Allah has willed. And if I knew the unseen, I could have acquired much wealth, and no harm would have touched me. I am not except a warner and a bringer of good tidings to a people who believe." (al-Araf/7: 188)

As a confirmation, Allah explains that every nation has a term appointed by Allah. That term will arrive when the time determined by Allah has arrived. The time of the arrival of that term is part of Allah's knowledge that cannot be known by anyone other than Him. So when their term has arrived, they are not able to postpone it for a moment, nor are they able to advance its time from the time that has been determined. Likewise, the Messenger of Allah (saw) will not have the power to determine the length of the term that Allah has determined.
text.50: Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (saw) to tell the polytheists to explain what they would do if Allah's promised punishment came suddenly. Whether it came at night while they were sound asleep, or during the day while they were busy with their affairs, would the sinful people then ask for it to be hastened? What is it that they desire? Do they desire the punishment of the Hereafter that will be inflicted upon them on the Day of Judgment? So whatever their choice, it only shows their narrow-mindedness and ignorance, because Allah's promise will surely come and no one can prevent it. This statement contains mockery towards them because generally, people who do evil and wallow in disobedience are afraid of the punishment that will be inflicted upon them. Sooner or later, the punishment will certainly come, and they will not be able to escape from it.
text.51: In this verse, Allah commands the Messenger to ask them whether the polytheists would only believe in Allah's threat to punish them after the punishment they feared had occurred. At that time, their faith would be of no use anymore, so what was the point of them constantly asking for the promised punishment to be hastened, or was the request to hasten it merely to show their attitude of constantly denying Allah's verses and responding with arrogance?
text.52: Allah explains that if they still refuse to believe, they should be told that they will experience Allah's punishment which will surely come and last forever. The punishment of Allah that will be inflicted upon them is a reward for what they did in this world. They will be given a reward commensurate with the deeds they have done according to their own choices, such as denying the truth of Allah's verses, associating partners with God (shirk), causing damage on earth, and their stubbornness in refusing to stop their hostility towards the Messenger of Allah, as well as denying the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection.
text.53:
Allah explains to the Prophet saw that the disbelieving Quraysh will ask him about a very important piece of news, namely regarding Allah's threat that will befall them, both worldly and Hereafter punishments. Will that promise truly happen, or is the threat merely news to frighten them? Such a question shows their own doubt, because when they deny Allah's verses, they will not believe the truth of their words because they are influenced by feelings of hostility towards the Prophet Muhammad saw and only blindly follow the beliefs of their ancestors. Faced with that question, the Messenger of Allah saw was commanded to answer that what was reported would truly happen. Even in that answer, Allah states with an oath that shows that the promise will indeed come to pass.

Allah's word:

"Indeed, the punishment of your Lord will surely come to pass. There is no repelling it." (ath-Thur/52: 7-8)

At the end of the verse, Allah emphasizes that if Allah has sent down the promised punishment upon them, then they will never escape that threat, even if they try to flee from that punishment.

Allah says:

"And we (the jinn) had thought that we could never escape Allah on earth, nor could we escape Him by flight." (al-Jinn/72: 12)
text.54:
Allah explains that if every person who wrongs themselves by associating partners with Allah, possessed all the wealth on earth, and were given the opportunity to ransom themselves, so that they might be saved from Allah's punishment with all the wealth they possessed, their transgression would certainly not be equal to their ransom. Moreover, at that time, repentance or ransom would no longer be accepted. There would be no protection for them to save themselves from Allah's punishment. Nevertheless, they try to hide their regret. This is because they have truly realized that all their efforts are useless, whether they scream as loudly as possible or remain completely silent. At that time, Allah's judgment has been decreed among them with the utmost justice. They will feel the recompense for all their actions, fanatically following their ancestors who remained immersed in polytheism.

If they receive such punishment, it cannot be said that Allah is oppressing them, but they themselves are oppressing themselves. Allah's punishment that will befall them is described as follows:

"Indeed, We have warned you of a near punishment on the Day when a man will see what his hands have put forth and the disbeliever will say, "Oh, I wish that I were dust!"" (an-Naba/78: 40)

And His saying:

"Oh, woe to me! I wish I had not taken so-and-so as a friend." (al-Furqan/25: 28)

And His saying:

"He had almost led me astray from the remembrance (the Quran) after it had come to me. And ever is Satan, to man, a deserter." (al-Furqan/25: 29)
text.55:
In this verse, Allah explains the signs of His power in implementing His laws, which cannot be hindered by anyone and cannot be redeemed with any kind of ransom, because the heavens, the earth, and everything in them belong to Allah. Allah calls upon all mankind to not neglect His provisions. What is meant by everything between the heavens and the earth in this verse is all natural objects, including intelligent creatures. This is intended to encourage humans to contemplate that the heavens, the earth, and all that is in them are under His supervision, and Allah establishes His laws according to His will. He can bestow favors upon His servants according to His will, and inflict punishment upon His creation according to His will as well.

Furthermore, Allah also affirms that any promise that Allah has established with His servants through His messengers is a true and certain promise that will come to pass, because Allah is powerful over everything, and is certainly powerful to fulfill His promise. No one can influence Him.

Then, Allah rebukes the majority of the polytheists because they always deny the verses of Allah and the Day of Resurrection, even though they have read the truth of the verses of Allah and have heard the guidance brought by the Messenger of Allah (saw). This shows that their judgment is no longer pure, but is influenced by their hostility towards the Prophet (saw) and their fanaticism towards the religion of their ancestors.
text.56: Allah emphasizes that He is the One who guides, who gives life and causes death. He has the power to determine the life and death of all creatures and living things in the heavens and the earth. There is no other Being that influences Him or hinders His will. He also has the power to resurrect mankind from their graves and return them to Him, on the promised Day, which is the Day of Recompense, when mankind will be judged and given recompense as is fitting, commensurate with their deeds.
text.57:
Allah calls out to all mankind that the Qur'an has been brought to them through His Messenger. Within it are contained guidelines for life that are very useful for their lives.

In this verse are mentioned the guidelines for life, as an answer to their denial of Allah's verses and His threats. This verse summarizes the function of the Al-Qur'an al-Karim in improving the human soul, including:

1. Mauidhah, which is a lesson from Allah to all mankind so that they love what is right and true, and avoid evil and wicked deeds. This lesson must truly be realized in their actions.

2. Syifa, which is a cure for diseases that reside in the human chest, such as the diseases of shirk, kufr, and hypocrisy, including all mental illnesses that disturb the peace of the human soul, such as hopelessness, weak resolve, indulging in desires, concealing feelings of envy and jealousy towards others, feelings of fear and cowardice, loving falsehood and evil, and hating truth and justice.

3. Huda, which is guidance to the straight path that saves mankind from misguided beliefs by guiding their minds and feelings to believe correctly by paying attention to the proofs of Allah's truth, and guiding them to be diligent in doing good deeds, by prioritizing the benefits they will obtain from sincere deeds and implementing the applicable legal rules, which actions are permissible and which actions must be avoided.

4. Rahmah, which is Allah's grace given to the believers, which they can reap from the guidance contained in the Qur'an. Believers who believe in and implement the guidance contained in the Qur'an will feel its fruits. They will live helping each other, loving each other, working together to uphold justice, eradicate evil and cruelty, and helping each other to achieve prosperity.

Allah says:

Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah; and those with him are forceful against the disbelievers, merciful among themselves. (al-Fath/48: 29)

And His saying:

Then he is among those who believed and advised one another to perseverance and advised one another to compassion. (al-Balad/90: 17)

The four qualities contained in this verse were created by Allah in accordance with the fitrah (natural disposition) of human creation. This means that, according to reason, humans have a tendency to accept good advice, accept teachings that can cure the turmoil of their souls, accept guidance that can be used as a guide for the happiness of their lives, and like to live in peace, loving and caring for each other.

The quality of rahmah is specifically for the believers in this verse, because they are the ones who want to make the Qur'an a guide, and carry out His commands and avoid His prohibitions. While the disbelievers and polytheists do not want to believe, let alone practice, its contents.
text.58:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to tell his Ummah that Allah's grace is the most important gift, exceeding other virtues given to them in the world. Therefore, Allah commanded them to rejoice and be grateful for the blessings they received, which exceed other pleasures.

The joy of the believers because of adhering firmly to the Qur'an is described in another verse as follows:

Allah says:

"And that day the believers will rejoice." (ar-Rum/30: 4)

And His saying:

"And those to whom We have given the Scripture rejoice at what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad]." (ar-Rad/13: 36)

It is said that Allah's grace and His Mercy are better than anything else they can achieve, because Allah's grace and His mercy emanating from the Qur'an are eternal for them, while other pleasures are fleeting and temporary, which they can only feel while they are navigating life in the world. When they return to the afterlife, the pleasures they can accumulate in the world are no longer useful to them.
text.59:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to say to the polytheists who deny the truth of revelation and the prophethood of Muhammad, whether all the sustenance that has been sent down to them, which is the source of their livelihood, whether plants or livestock, can be determined by them alone as lawful or unlawful. Whereas it is clear that the One who created all of it is Allah. Therefore, they have no right to determine its lawfulness. That is why Allah commands His Messenger to say to them that the One who has the right to determine the law is the One who created all of it, namely Allah. Or do they assume that Allah has given them permission to determine the law, or do they do so only by fabricating in the name of Allah, or is it just their assumption that what they have determined is in accordance with Allah's provisions, that is, what they have forbidden is what Allah has forbidden, and what they have permitted is what Allah has permitted? The first possibility, that they received permission from Allah, is impossible because they themselves have denied the revelation itself, so the second possibility is the one that can occur, namely that they determine the law only on the basis of mere conjecture, or in other words, they fabricate in the name of Allah.

And they set aside a portion of the crops and livestock for Allah, while saying according to their assumption, "This is for Allah, and this is for our idols." The portion for their idols will not reach Allah, and the portion for Allah will reach their idols. How evil is their judgment. (al-Anam/6: 136)
text.60:
Allah reveals the error in their assumption that on the Day of Judgment, everyone will be rewarded according to their deeds, that they will not be held accountable, that they will not be punished for lying in the name of Allah, or for assuming that they have the right to determine the law, the permissibility and prohibition of something. This error of theirs is what leads them to a greater error, namely that they deliberately dare to interfere in matters that are actually Allah's right, oppose the revelation sent down from Allah, and associate partners with Allah in the form of other gods.

They (the jinn) worked for Solomon according to his desire, including (making) tall buildings, statues, dishes (as large as) pools, and stationary pots (on the stove). "Work, O family of David, in gratitude (to Allah)." And few of My servants are grateful. (Saba/34: 13)

Allah explains the reason why they must receive punishment, which is because of their own mistakes. Allah has bestowed His immense favor upon mankind, namely sending down revelation to be used as a guide for their lives, so that they may live happily in this world and the hereafter, and has determined the permissibility and prohibition of all things, so that they may be guided to a prosperous and peaceful life. Allah has sent down various kinds of sustenance to meet their needs.

At the end of the verse, Allah regrets why most people do not want to be grateful for all kinds of blessings that have been given to them, and even oppress themselves by opposing the provisions and laws that Allah has established. They do not want to take the revelation that has been sent down to them as a guide. Most of them live following their desires and squandering their wealth, because of feelings of arrogance and self-pride.
text.61:
Allah explains to His Messenger and the Muslims that at the time the Messenger of Allah is carrying out important matters concerning the interests of the community, at the time of reciting the verses of the Qur'an, and at the time humans are performing their deeds, nothing escapes Allah's observation. He witnesses all those deeds at the time they are done.

Included in the important matters in this verse are all kinds of matters concerning the interests of the ummah, such as the affairs of Islamic da'wah, which is inviting the ummah to follow the straight path, in a wise manner and with good example, awakening the ummah's awareness to be interested in carrying out religious commands and avoiding His prohibitions, including the affairs of educating the ummah and ways to realize that education into a reality that is beneficial for the welfare of the ummah. It is also mentioned that the verses of the Qur'an that are recited encompass all matters based on the patterns of their implementation, and should not deviate from them, because the affairs of the entire ummah have been fundamentally arranged in that book.

Then, all the deeds performed by His servants are mentioned, which have been outlined by the revelation revealed to His Messenger, by using the contents of that revelation as a guide in their daily affairs, and obeying the Messenger, because what the Messenger says and does becomes a good example for the entire ummah.

Allah emphasizes that all kinds of deeds performed by His servants, none of them escape Allah's knowledge and observation, even if the deed is smaller than the smallest object, or the matter is so important that it cannot be controlled by humans. The mention of matters that are smaller than the smallest and matters that are of utmost importance is so that it is depicted in the hearts of His servants that Allah's knowledge is so perfect that not a single matter escapes His knowledge, no matter how trivial the matter is and how important the matter is, especially if the matter is beyond human capability.

Allah's knowledge not only encompasses all kinds of matters that exist on earth, but also encompasses all kinds of matters in the heavens, whose affairs are more complex and more difficult to imagine in human minds. This is to strengthen the meaning of the vastness of Allah's knowledge, so that His greatness and power are felt.

At the end of this verse, Allah states firmly that there is not a single matter that is not recorded in a clear book, namely *Lauh Mahfudh*, meaning that all kinds of matters are all controlled and governed and mastered by the knowledge of Allah, the Most Vast, and recorded in His clear book in *Lauh Mahfudh*.

Allah says:

"And with Him are the keys of the unseen; none knows them except Him. And He knows what is on the land and in the sea. Not a leaf falls but that He knows it. And no grain is there within the darknesses of the earth and no moist or dry [thing] but that it is [written] in a clear record (Lauh Mahfudh)." (al-Anam/6: 59)
text.62:
In this verse, Allah directs the attention of the Muslims so that they have full awareness that indeed the *wali*-s of Allah will not feel anxiety or distress.

The *wali*-s of Allah in this verse are those who believe and are pious (*taqwa*), as a designation for those who defend the religion of Allah and those who uphold His laws in the midst of society, and as the opposite of those who are hostile to His religion, such as the polytheists and the disbelievers (see tafsir Surah al-Anam/6: 51-55).

It is said that there is no fear for them, because they are certain that the promise of Allah will surely come, and His help will certainly arrive, and His guidance will certainly lead them to the straight path. And if a disaster befalls them, they remain patient in facing and overcoming it with full perseverance and reliance (*tawakal*) on Allah. (see tafsir Surah al-Baqarah/2: 249).

Their hearts are also not distressed, because they have believed and are content that everything that happens under the laws of Allah is in His grasp. They are not distressed because of parting with the world, with all its great pleasures. They are not afraid of receiving the punishment of Allah on the Day of Judgment because they and all their hearts have been surrendered to the interests of religion. They do not feel they have lost anything, because they have obtained guidance of immeasurable value (see tafsir Surah al-Baqarah/2: 2 and al-Anfal/8: 29).
text.63: Allah explains who is meant by the blessed *wali*-s of Allah and why they are so. The explanation found in this verse indicates that a *wali* is one who believes and is pious (*bertaqwa*). What is meant by believing here is one who believes in Allah, in His angels, in His books, in His messengers, in the Last Day, that all events, good and bad, are from Allah, and who carries out what should be done by those who believe. While what is meant by *bertaqwa* is to protect oneself from all actions that are contrary to the laws of Allah, both the laws of Allah that regulate the order of the universe, or the *hukum syara* that regulate the order of human life in the world (see the commentary of Surah al-Anfal/8: 10).
text.64:
Allah explains that they receive glad tidings, which they feel in their lives in this world and in the Hereafter. These glad tidings that they receive are the glad tidings that Allah has promised through His Messenger. In this world, these glad tidings include the victory they obtain in upholding the word of Allah, success in life because they follow the correct path, and the hope they obtain as caliphs on earth. As long as they adhere to the law of Allah and defend the truth of Allah's religion, they will receive *husnul khatimah* (a good ending). As for the glad tidings that they will receive in the Hereafter, they are salvation from the torment of the grave, from the touch of hellfire, and their eternal abode in the Garden of 'Adn (see tafsir Surah al-Anfal/8: 10).

Allah affirms that there is no change in Allah's promises. This means that the glad tidings that Allah has promised in His Book and established by the words of His Messenger, both the promises of Allah that they receive in this world and those that they will receive in the Hereafter, will not change because it is the fruit of true faith, which they live by, and the *taqwa* (piety) that they practice.

At the end of this verse, Allah states that what they obtain is a glorious victory that has no equal in the world, namely the happiness of life in Paradise and freedom from the torment of hellfire.
text.65:
Allah forbids the Muslims from feeling anxious and troubled because of the words of the polytheists who oppose the religion of Allah and deny Allah's revelation, because indeed, victory, strength, and protection are not theirs to possess, but Allah is the One who has the power to grant all of it to His creatures according to His will. The Muslims are forbidden to fear facing the polytheists simply because of their large numbers (see tafsir Surah al-Anfal/8: 10).

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is the All-Hearing of the words of the polytheists who deny the Messenger and deny the truth of revelation. The All-Knowing of their actions taken against the Prophet and his followers, such as their deception to defeat the religion of monotheism and their persecution of the Prophet and his followers.
text.66:
This verse reminds Muslims that everything in the heavens and on earth is under the dominion of Allah, including the idols they worship and associate with Allah. The polytheists associate Allah with other gods not based on true belief, but only on conjecture. They worship idols because of the assumption that the idols they worship can help them and bring them closer to Allah, so that their prayers will be answered by Allah. Such assumptions arise in their minds because they consider Allah to be the same as their cruel and tyrannical leaders and dignitaries. If they want to communicate with their superiors or want to submit a request to them, the request will not be accepted or receive proper service unless it first goes through the right hand of their leader.

At the end of the verse, Allah affirms that the polytheists follow such assumptions because of ignorance that will not lead them to the truth in the slightest.
text.67:
Allah affirms to the Muslims that He is the One who created the night for mankind, so that mankind can rest at that time. He also created the bright daytime by the light of the sun so that mankind can seek His bounty at that time. The alternation of day and night is regulated by Allah with His laws. With His laws, celestial bodies orbit in their predetermined orbits. In regulating the movement of celestial bodies, Allah does not need other gods to help, but solely with His supreme wisdom, Allah is powerful to regulate the movement of those bodies. Because of the movement of these celestial bodies, differences in time and changes in weather arise, so that mankind can choose the appropriate time to meet the needs of their lives and fulfill their obligations to their Creator.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that those who truly pay attention to the verses recited by the Messenger of Allah (saw) and think carefully about their contents, and pay attention to Allah's laws that apply in the universe, will certainly acknowledge the oneness and power of Allah.
text.68:
Allah explains to the Muslims that the Jews, Christians, and polytheists say that Allah has a child, such as the belief of the Jews that Uzair is the son of Allah, the belief of the Christians that Isa Al-Masih is the son of Allah, and the polytheists' assumption that the angels are the daughters of Allah. Allah refutes their assumptions and accusations. How could these accusations be justified, since He is the All-Creator, Possessor, and Self-Sufficient? Indeed, the heavens, the earth, and everything in between are His creation. He is the Sovereign. Allah does not need all these things; on the contrary, they are the ones who need Allah. If humans need children, it is fitting, because children continue their lineage and become their pride. However, Allah does not need children because He is the one who created humans and their offspring.

Allah emphasizes that the People of the Book and the polytheists who hold such views have no reason whatsoever to prove the truth of their assumptions; in fact, these assumptions only demonstrate their own ignorance. That is why Allah states at the end of this verse that they are saying something they themselves do not know to be true, which is a great ignorance. Moreover, after they have received clarification from the revealed verses that are recited, and they still maintain their assumptions, this shows their obstinacy. From this verse, we can learn that a person who says something without having a reason demonstrates their own ignorance.
text.69: Allah commanded His Messenger to say to those who associate partners with Him, or those who say that Allah has a son, that those who attribute such ignorance to Allah like them will not prosper. What they hope for, such as their salvation from the torment of hellfire, and a happy life thanks to the help of the idols they deify, will not come to pass.
text.70: Allah provides an explanation that they obtain temporary pleasure in the world, deceived by the fleeting pleasures of this world. The pleasures of this world, when compared to the pleasures of the hereafter, are meaningless. Then, on the Day of Resurrection, they will be returned to Allah. At that time, they will be gathered in the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar), and held accountable for all the actions they committed in the world. Then Allah will give them punishment commensurate with their deeds, namely a painful punishment that is indescribable, due to their denial of the verses of Allah and their lies against the Prophet Muhammad (saw).
text.71:
Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to relate to the polytheists of Mecca an important event in the story of Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) and his people. Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) declared to his people his firm determination to continue spreading the religion of Allah while surrendering all decisions completely to Allah. He did not care whether his people objected to his presence among them to call them to worship Allah, or whether they objected to the warnings he conveyed about the proofs of Allah's oneness.

Thanks to his firm determination and reliance (tawakkal), Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) did not hesitate to challenge his people to finalize their decision, including their deities, to destroy him. He even encouraged them to make the plan openly, not secretly. Then, when the plan was mature with open agreement, Prophet Noah called on them to immediately carry out the plan to kill him and not delay it.
text.72: This verse explains that Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) said to his people that he would not ask for any reward from them and would not obtain any worldly benefit from his preaching mission, except for reward and recompense from Allah. Therefore, there was no reason for them to turn away from his call. If they turned away from his warnings and calls, Prophet Noah would not be harmed or troubled in the slightest. He was commanded to be one who upholds all of Allah's commands and submits himself to Him.
text.73:
This verse explains that even though Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) had presented the truth of his call and invitation with logical reasons, his people continued to deny him and reject his prophethood. Because the possibility of their believing had been closed, God's punishment was sent down upon them in the form of a violent hurricane and a great flood that drowned them. Prophet Noah and the believers with him were saved by Allah from the hurricane disaster. They boarded an ark that they had built before the hurricane attack, according to Allah's guidance. They were the ones who became the inhabitants of the earth and replaced the people who had perished, namely those who denied the verses of Allah. In one of His words, Allah says:

And how many generations have We destroyed after Noah. And sufficient is your Lord as All-Aware and All-Seeing of the sins of His servants. (al-Isra/17: 17)

Allah then taught Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to convey this news to those who continuously deny the Messenger. What the people of Prophet Noah experienced will certainly be experienced by his people if they continue to deny his prophethood.
text.74:
In this verse, Allah explains the sending of messengers after the event of Prophet Noah's flood (peace be upon him). Among the prophets sent were Prophet Hud, Saleh, Ibrahim, Lut, and Shuaib (peace be upon them). They were sent to their respective peoples; Prophet Hud to the people of 'Ad, Prophet Saleh to the people of Thamud, and Shuaib was sent to his people, the inhabitants of Madyan, and also to the people of Aikah, their neighbors. These two peoples were actually of the same stock, they had the same language and the same homeland. Each prophet came to his people with evidence of the truth of his prophethood and gave guidance to that people. Each prophet outlined guidelines for life for his people in accordance with the time, situation, and circumstances of their environment.

Most of the peoples of the prophets did not believe, and even denied them, just like the people of Noah. The habit of blind imitation of their leaders was always followed by the next generation. Therefore, like the hearts of their ancestors, their hearts were locked shut, so the conscience of the next generation was also locked. This was a result of their transgressions.

The hearts of the Arab polytheists who opposed Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) were as dark as those of past nations. Their hearts were closed to receiving the truth. They denied the Messenger and were disobedient. The *Sunnah* of Allah remains in effect for those who challenge and deny the religion. If the Arab polytheists continue to disbelieve, they will be afflicted with the punishment of God, just like the past nations. Allah says:

As was the *Sunnah* of Allah for those who passed on before; and you will never find in the *Sunnah* of Allah any change. (al-Ahzab/33: 62)
text.75:
After explaining the sending of the messengers to their respective peoples, in this verse, Allah specifically explains the sending of Musa and Harun (peace be upon them) to Pharaoh and the leaders of his people. The story of Musa (peace be upon him) is repeated many times in the Quran, because this story contains important lessons. Musa (peace be upon him) was a messenger of Allah who was confronted by a king, Pharaoh, who possessed great power and was the king of a country with a high level of civilization and culture. Because of his greatness, he became arrogant and tyrannical towards his people. He was surrounded by the leaders of his people (the Coptic nation) who had a great influence on him and greatly misled his thinking. The indigenous people of Egypt were greatly influenced by these leaders. If their leaders disbelieved, then they too disbelieved; if they believed, then they also believed. All their affairs and interests were always dependent on these leaders.

When Prophet Musa proved the truth of his prophethood with several miracles, they still refused to believe due to the arrogance that resided in their hearts. Their minds actually acknowledged the truth of Musa's prophethood (peace be upon him). They could distinguish between magic and what was not magic (miracles) because they knew what it actually was. However, they still disbelieved, because they were people full of sin.

Allah says:

"And they rejected them [those signs] while their [inner] selves were convinced thereof, out of injustice and arrogance. Then see how was the end of the corrupters." (an-Naml/27: 14)
text.76: In this verse, it is explained that the leaders of Pharaoh's people considered the miracles and proofs of truth to be obvious magic to those who witnessed and observed them. Their accusation was very bad, because those who made the accusation were fully aware that it was not true. The extraordinary miracle brought forth by Musa (peace be upon him) was not his own doing, but the event was a miracle that occurred by the power of Allah.
text.77: Allah explains Musa a.s.'s rebuttal that it is not fitting for them to utter accusations of magic against the signs of Allah's power in the form of miracles when they were brought to them. Their own eyes witnessed extraordinary and terrifying events. If those events were merely magic, then at another time they could be defeated by magic as well. But it became a reality that their magicians did not succeed in defeating the miracle of Prophet Musa. Magicians will not succeed in gaining victory with their magic. Magic is a conjuring trick; sooner or later, its falsehood and deception will be exposed.
text.78: In this verse, Allah explains the attitude of the leaders of the Coptic people, after they failed to present strong arguments to refute the truth of the Prophet Musa (peace be upon him). They then sought excuses to defend and maintain their traditions or customs. They accused Musa of coming to them to force them to abandon the customs and traditions they had inherited from their ancestors, and then forcing them to follow the religion of Prophet Musa. According to them, Musa's efforts were aimed at becoming the religious and state leader in Egypt together with his brother Harun. Their negative assumptions about Musa's arrival and his purpose made them determined not to believe in the teachings he brought and not to become his followers.
text.79: Then in this verse, Allah explains Pharaoh's attitude after being influenced by the leaders of his people with their accusations and negative views towards Moses. He then ordered them to summon skilled magicians so that they could compete with and destroy the miracle of Prophet Moses. Pharaoh's action was to preserve his status, glory, and position, as well as to hinder the development of Moses' power and the Children of Israel in his kingdom.
text.80: Then, after the magicians were summoned to an open field, they came to Moses to offer him the choice of whether he would cast his staff first or whether they would begin. Moses allowed them to show their magic first. So they threw their ropes and staffs. With the power of magic, the ropes and staffs turned into snakes. They captivated the sight of the people, frightening the hearts of those who witnessed it.
text.81: After they finished demonstrating their magic, Musa said to them, without paying any attention to the awesomeness of the magic they had shown, that what they had done was merely magic, or an attempt to distort people's vision. In reality, there was no change that occurred with the transformation of the staffs and ropes into snakes. Whereas what Musa was about to do was a miracle from the power of Allah. Allah would nullify that trickery with the miracle brought by Prophet Musa a.s. It is clear that magic is the work of humans, not an extraordinary event. Then Musa threw his staff, and Allah transformed the staff into a snake, and the snake swallowed the magic snakes they had made because Allah would not allow the actions of the magicians to continue.
text.82: Allah affirms that He, with His words (kalimah-Nya), strengthens the truth. With that truth, humanity will achieve prosperity and be protected from injustice. The words of Allah are the rules of Allah instilled into the sharia that was conveyed to His messengers. With those words, Musa (Moses) was able to defeat Pharaoh and free the Children of Israel from Pharaoh's enslavement, even though this was disliked by Pharaoh and his leaders.
text.83:
In this verse, Allah explains the situation of Moses and his people before they left Egypt. The failure of Pharaoh, along with the leaders of his people and the magicians, prompted Pharaoh to commit even more cruel acts. He planned the murder of Prophet Moses and the Children of Israel. This plan instilled fear among the Children of Israel. Therefore, not many of them believed in Prophet Moses. Those who believed were generally young people. The people of Prophet Moses were afraid of Pharaoh and the leaders of his people, who were constantly trying to torture them and force them to renounce the religion of Moses (peace be upon him). The Pharaoh of Moses' time (peace be upon him) was among the most cruel kings in the history of Egypt. Therefore, he was greatly feared by his people. He shed much human blood, and he also considered himself to be God. The Children of Israel were made slaves in the land of Egypt.

Allah's word explains the cruelty of Pharaoh:

"And the chiefs of Pharaoh's people said, "Will you leave Moses and his people to cause corruption in the land and abandon you and your gods?" He said, "We will kill their sons and keep their women alive; and indeed, we are dominant over them." (al-Araf/7: 127)
text.84: After Moses saw the believers in a state of fear, he called upon them to put their trust in Allah if they truly believed in Him, accompanied by complete submission and obedience to Allah's commands and prohibitions. Faith without practical application of the teachings of Allah and His Messenger is meaningless faith. Trust in Allah (tawakkal) will be born from the soul of a believer who obediently practices the teachings of his religion to the best of his ability. This verse indicates that not all of the Children of Israel believed in Moses while they were in Egypt. In addition to believing in Allah, one must believe in the Messenger. Only then does one become a Muslim who submits and obeys the commands and prohibitions of the religion brought by that Messenger. The Jews, after safely leaving the land of Egypt and arriving in Sinai, demanded that Moses make an idol of God for them. Then, when they were left by Moses, who was going to receive revelation on Mount Sinai, they made a calf as God and worshipped it. This event shows that not all Jews believed in and obeyed the teachings of Moses (peace be upon him).
text.85: Those who believed and were obedient, when they heard the call of Moses, they immediately responded to it with full obedience, even placing their trust solely in Allah. They realized that the victory and happiness promised by the Lord to those who believe depends on their faith, deeds, and *tawakkal*. Then, after *tawakkal*, they prayed to Allah to protect them from the evil of the unjust people and to shield them from the efforts of those who wanted to turn them away from religion.
text.86: This verse explains the continuation of the Children of Israel's prayer when they pleaded to Allah to be released from the power and cruelty of Pharaoh and the leaders of his people. For centuries they were in Pharaoh's servitude and they experienced forced labor and other degrading and inhumane menial tasks.
text.87: Allah commanded Moses and Aaron to seek out several houses in the city of Egypt to be used as dwellings and shelters for their people, as well as places for their activities. Allah commanded that these houses be made places of prayer (salat). Then, specifically to Moses as the bearer of the Sharia, Allah commanded him to give good tidings in the future to those who believe in Allah and His Messenger. In these shelters, Prophet Moses filled their inner selves with religious teachings and instilled in their souls faith and noble character.
text.88:
This verse explains the defiance and arbitrary actions of Pharaoh and the leaders of his people, the anxiety and fear of the Children of Israel, and Moses' complaint to Allah about the abundant blessings bestowed upon Pharaoh and his people, such as gold and jewel ornaments, luxurious ceremonial robes, and other riches, but all the blessings given by Allah only led them astray from the path of Allah. They even became more arrogant and committed injustice with that wealth. Allah seemed to allow them to remain in their error, so they did not believe.

Then Prophet Moses prayed for the destruction of Pharaoh and the leaders of his people for the following reasons:

First, disbelief in Allah's blessings. It is a fact that Pharaoh and the leaders of his people possessed great power and strength. In addition, science and technology reached their peak in Pharaoh's time in Egypt. Pharaoh's artifacts, whether found in Egyptian museums or in Europe and America, demonstrate the height of their civilization and culture. Similarly, the ancient artifacts and buildings found in Egypt. In government, Pharaoh held absolute power, even claiming himself as a god to his people.

Second, rejecting the truth. Reality shows that Pharaoh and the leaders of his people had strayed far from the moral values of humanity and religion. Human rights were not respected. They lived in luxury, at the expense of the suffering of the people. Moses (peace be upon him) had tried to bring Pharaoh and his dignitaries to the path of Allah, by showing evidence of his prophethood. He gave teachings about truth, justice, advice and warnings of Allah's punishment, and disasters, as a result of their actions. However, Moses' call did not receive a good response but rather faced challenges and hostility. Thus, the possibility of calling Pharaoh and his people to the path of Allah was closed, and their faith could no longer be hoped for.

Allowing Pharaoh and his dignitaries to continue with their power, glory, and great strength, while the basic principles of their lives were far below the moral values of humanity and religion, greatly endangered world peace and the welfare of mankind. With their strength and power, they committed sins and caused corruption on earth, threatening the safety of mankind. Therefore, Prophet Moses offered a prayer to Allah for the happiness of mankind, that Allah would paralyze Pharaoh's power by allowing them to remain in their error, because their error would lead to their own destruction. Prophet Aaron, as Prophet Moses' main assistant, affirmed Prophet Moses' prayer.
text.89: In this verse, Allah states to Musa and Harun that their prayer for the destruction of Pharaoh and his power will be granted by God. This has already become Allah's decree. Then, Allah commands Musa and Harun to continue carrying out His commands and to continue conveying the call to the path of Allah and preparing the Children of Israel to struggle and move to leave the land of Egypt. Allah forbids following the path of those who do not follow the Sunnah of God upon His creation, which is the law of cause and effect, such as demanding the immediate destruction of Pharaoh before its time or asking for the destruction to be delayed from the appointed time. The time of Pharaoh's downfall will surely come, because they cannot escape from God's law.
text.90:
In this verse, Allah recounts the departure of the Children of Israel from the land of Egypt. When Prophet Musa (Moses) requested Pharaoh to release the Children of Israel in Egypt from the shackles of slavery and allow them to return to Palestine to practice their religion freely, Pharaoh rejected the request.

Eventually, Musa and his people fled Egypt. Pharaoh and his army then pursued them. Pharaoh and his army were about to overtake Musa and his people as they were about to cross the sea. The Children of Israel were afraid of being captured by Pharaoh's forces, but Musa reassured his group by convincing them that they would witness the destruction of their enemies. Then, God revealed to Musa to strike the sea with his staff. The sea split, and Musa and his people entered, walking through its dry gaps until they arrived safely on the other side of the sea. Pharaoh and his army followed the same path, but when they reached the middle of the journey, Musa stretched out his hand towards the sea, and the sea returned to its original state. Pharaoh drowned, swallowed by the waves along with his army. When he felt he was about to die drowning, he declared his faith and Islam. He declared belief in the God believed in by the Children of Israel. His declaration of faith in Allah and Musa a.s. was uttered with the words: "I am among the Muslims." The declaration of Islam contains faith in Allah and His Messenger, but this declaration of faith was very late because it was declared when he was about to drown and no one could help him. A declaration in such a state is not accepted by Allah. Allah says:

"Then, when they saw Our punishment, they said, "We believe in Allah alone and disbelieve in that which we used to associate with Him." But never did their faith benefit them once they saw Our punishment. [That is] the established way of Allah which has ever obtained among His servants. And thereupon the disbelievers lost." (Ghafir/40: 84-85)
text.91: In this verse, Allah recounts the state of Pharaoh when, in despair, he declared his faith. It was said to him that it was not fitting for him to profess faith and Islam at such a time, because that declaration was only to avoid death and seek salvation from disaster, after he had been overcome by despair. Whereas, in the past, he had denied Allah, even claiming himself to be God, thus acting arbitrarily towards his fellow human beings and committing injustice on earth. Therefore, such a declaration of faith and Islam is not accepted because it does not arise from sincerity, but from despair.
text.92: Then, in this verse, Allah explains that on the day of his death, Pharaoh's corpse would be brought out from the depths of the sea and cast onto the land so that those who doubted his death would be certain and it would be a lesson for people thereafter. No matter how great and vast a person's power and strength may be, if he opposes the commands of Allah and abandons the guidance of His Messenger, he will surely experience destruction. Allah's promise to help His prophets will certainly be fulfilled. Many signs of Allah's power are found in the history of mankind. But most people do not want to contemplate those signs and do not realize the divine law that applies to mankind.
text.93:
After Allah concluded the story of Pharaoh, in this verse, Allah mentions the history of the Children of Israel, upon their arrival at the place promised by the Lord. Allah had placed them in a beautiful land, namely the land of Palestine. As explained in another verse, Allah says:

"And We caused the people who were oppressed to inherit the eastern lands and the western lands, which We had blessed." (al-A'raf/7: 137)

Allah bestowed good and various kinds of sustenance upon the Children of Israel, such as livestock, plantations, agriculture, and fisheries on land, such as the Dead Sea, and in the sea. They lived harmoniously and peacefully, full of happiness in the new land. But then a great dispute arose among them after they studied the Torah and its laws. It was actually inappropriate for them to disagree because Allah had clearly explained His law to them. If disputes arose, it was due to personal factors and the interests of groups among them. Allah says:

"And those who were given the Scripture did not differ except after knowledge had come to them - out of jealous animosity between themselves." (ali Imran/3: 19)
