Envy and hatred towards other groups, personal ambition, boasting, group interests, and subjective factors greatly influenced the Jews in studying the Holy Book. They did not hesitate to distort the meaning of verses from their true meaning. Allah says:

"(Some) among the Jews distort words from their [proper] usages..." (an-Nisa/4: 46)
text.94:
Allah explains the attitude of the Jewish and Christian priests towards the Books of Allah that were revealed to the messengers sent to them by saying, "If you, O Muhammad, are in doubt about the messengers of old and the books that were revealed to them, then ask the Jewish and Christian priests who have knowledge of and read the books that We revealed before We revealed the Qur'an to you."

According to the Arabic language, the expression in this verse is not to explain Muhammad's doubt, but to state that Muhammad is truly certain and believes in the messengers sent by Allah and the books revealed to them. Only the Jews and Christians doubt. They deliberately create their doubts to cover up what is actually in their hearts, which is to believe in the truth of Muhammad's message and prophethood.

Therefore, the meaning of this verse is that Allah states to Muhammad that he (Prophet Muhammad) is certain and believes that what was revealed to you is the truth and a truth that must be believed. Only the Jews and Christians doubt. Their doubts are expressed solely to cover up their actions of changing and exchanging the contents of the Torah and the Gospel. They have read the Torah and the Gospel which explain the principles of religion that are pleasing to Allah, the messengers that Allah has sent and will send in the future. But it is their desires that command them to commit forbidden acts, so that they mislead their followers. Therefore, in reality, the Jewish and Christian priests know very well what is right and what is wrong. If they are asked about something that is true, they will surely be able to answer it correctly. But they do not want to do it.

This verse is a satire to the Jewish and Christian priests and reveals the sinful acts they have committed.

Such an expression is also found in other words of Allah, as in the following verse:

And [beware the Day] when Allah will say, "O Jesus, Son of Mary, did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?'" (al-Maidah/5: 116)

If this verse is read at a glance, it will be understood as if Jesus commanded his people to acknowledge the existence of a father god, a son god, and a mother god. But the meaning of this verse is to explain that Jesus, peace be upon him, never doubted the oneness of God. Only the Christians who have changed and exchanged the contents of the Gospel claim that God is three, such as exchanging the principle of the oneness of Allah contained therein with the principle of shirk.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains the attitude of the Messenger of Allah, the Jews and the Christians. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, believed in Allah and in the Qur'an that was revealed to him and believed in His oneness, while the Jews and Christians changed and exchanged the contents of the Torah and the Gospel and associated partners with Him. Then Allah warns the Muslims not to ever commit acts like those committed by the Christians and Jews.
text.95: Allah emphasizes again that Muhammad and the Muslims should not be among those who deny the verses of Allah, as the Jews and Christians have done, because such an act will cause great loss to those who do it in this world and in the hereafter.
text.96: This verse explains that for those who deny the verses of Allah, Allah's decrees apply, which is to punish them with a painful torment in the Hereafter. Their faith can no longer be hoped for, because their hearts have been sealed and locked shut, unable to receive divine guidance, so they remain in disbelief and sinful deeds.
text.97: Those whose hearts are sealed will not believe, even if various kinds of evidence and signs of Allah's power and oneness are presented to them. They will only believe after being cast into Hell, when they feel the painful torment. But their faith will no longer be accepted, because the door of repentance will have been closed at that time.
text.98:
This verse explains that the best attitude for a people to adopt is when a messenger calls them to believe in Allah by presenting evidence of the truth of his call, and they are willing to respond to the messenger's call by believing and implementing the message he brings. Such faith is beneficial and advantageous because it is done when a person is able to bear the burden that Allah places upon him (taklif). Faith is not beneficial for a person if he is in a state of not being subject to taklif, such as the faith of Pharaoh when he was about to drown in the middle of the sea, and like the faith of the disbelievers when they are being punished in hell. Faith at that time is no longer accepted.

The people of Prophet Yunus were a people who believed in a state of taklif, so that faith was beneficial for them. Prophet Yunus was sent to the inhabitants of the city of Nainawa (Nineveh) to convey the religion of Allah, but they denied the call. Yunus explained to them that if they did not believe, Allah would send down punishment upon them after three days. On the third day, Yunus avoided that land. On the promised morning, they saw a sign of the coming of the punishment. Therefore, they searched for Yunus, but they did not find him. Then they gathered together with their families and livestock in the open field, pleading to Allah that the promised punishment would not be inflicted upon them, and they declared their faith in Him. Allah accepted their repentance and canceled the sending down of punishment upon them. Then Allah gave them the pleasure of life until the end of their lives, as a reward for their faith.
text.99:
This verse explains that if Allah willed for all of humanity to believe in Him, it would be accomplished, because doing so is easy for Him. But He does not will that. He wills to implement His Sunnah in His creation. No one can change His Sunnah except if He Himself wills it. Among His Sunnah is giving humans intellect, thought, and feelings that distinguish them from angels and other creatures. With intellect, thought, and feelings, humans become cultured beings, able to distinguish between what is good and what is bad, good for themselves, for others, and for the universe. Then, human deeds are rewarded according to the deeds they have done; good deeds are rewarded with blessings, and evil and bad deeds are rewarded with punishment.

In addition, Allah sent messengers to convey His religion, which explains to humans what is good to do and what is forbidden to do. Humans, with the intellect, thought, and feelings that Allah has bestowed upon them, can evaluate what the messengers convey. There is no compulsion for humans in determining their choices, good or bad. And humans will be judged based on their choices.
text.100: Everything that happens in this universe is by the will of Allah. Nothing happens outside of His will. Allah guides and makes it easy for someone to believe, if that person wants to understand and practice the verses that have been conveyed to His messengers. And He views with contempt and punishes everyone who does not want to understand and practice His verses because it means they reject the invitation of the messenger to follow the straight path that He has laid out.
text.101:
In this verse, Allah explains His command to His Messenger, that he should call upon his people to observe with their own eyes and minds all the events in the heavens and the earth. They are commanded to contemplate the wonders of the heavens filled with stars, the sun, and the moon, the beauty of the alternation of night and day, the rainwater that falls to the earth, reviving the dead earth, and growing plants and trees with fruits of various colors and tastes. Animals with various shapes and colors live on earth, providing considerable benefits to humans. Likewise, the state of the earth itself, consisting of deserts, vast valleys, fertile plains, oceans full of various kinds of fish, all of which are signs of the oneness and power of Allah, for those who are willing to think and believe in their Creator.

However, for those who do not believe in the existence of the Creator of this universe, because their human nature (fitrah insaniah) does not function as it should, all these signs of the oneness and power of Allah in this universe are of no benefit to them.

Likewise, the warnings of the prophets do not affect their souls. Their minds and feelings are unable to learn from the verses of Allah and do not lead them to the conviction of the existence of Allah, the One and Only. They do not learn from the Sunnah of Allah upon mankind in the past. If they had learned from the verses of Allah and from the Sunnah of Allah upon mankind, their souls would surely be cleansed and preserved from the dirt and filth that drives them to disbelief and error.
text.102: Then, in these verses, Allah gives a warning and a threat to the Arab polytheists that punishment will soon befall them, as experienced by the people before them who also denied the messengers and disbelieved in them. Do these polytheists reject the prophethood of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, because they want to wait for Allah's punishment first? Allah calls upon the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, to tell them to wait for that torment. Allah's wrath will certainly come upon them if they continue to deny and disbelieve in the prophethood of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. The Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, along with the believers will also wait for their destruction. In accordance with Allah's promise and His Sunnah, that the disbelievers will surely perish.
text.103:
In this verse, Allah explains that in accordance with His Sunnah that applies to the messengers and their believing people, Allah will save and protect them from destruction. That is Allah's decree, and Allah will not change His decree.

Allah says:

(Such was Our way with the messengers We sent before you, and you will find no change in Our ways.) (al-Isra/17: 77)
text.104:
Allah commanded the Messenger (saw) to say to his people that if they doubted the truth of the religion he brought, which taught about the oneness of Allah, then they should have doubted the beliefs they held onto first. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad (saw) declared to them that he would not worship idols and statues that they worshipped, which had no ability whatsoever. But he would worship the Lord, the Creator, Who determines the life and death of His creatures. He is the One who gives pleasure and hardship, benefit and harm, according to His wisdom and *inayah* (care, providence), not a god like the ones they worshipped.

With that comparison, the truth of the religion brought by the Messenger (saw) and the error of the beliefs of the *mushrikin* (polytheists) became clearer. Then the Prophet Muhammad (saw) said to the Arab *mushrikin* that he was commanded to be among the believers. Allah has promised those who believe safety from punishment, victory over their enemies, and power on earth.
text.105: In this verse, it is explained that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was commanded to turn his face and his entire being to Allah, focusing his attention on religious duties and serving the Lord of the universe. This is because if he gave attention to anything other than Allah, it would diminish the completeness of his soul in facing the Lord and his devotion to his religion. To Allah alone should the purpose of all his devotion, both outwardly and inwardly, be directed. He should not be among those who associate partners with Allah in worship with deities, jinn, spirits, or idols, as is the case with idol worshippers. Allah's prohibition to the Messenger (peace be upon him) is intended to encourage and stimulate the Messenger (peace be upon him) to continue to avoid the characteristics of shirk.
text.106: Allah explains His prohibition to the Prophet (saw) against praying and worshipping to other than Allah. Because other than Allah, there is nothing that can give benefit and harm, or give pleasure and hardship, both in this world and in the hereafter. If the Messenger were to do so, then he would be among those who wrong themselves. There is no disobedience greater than shirk because the person who commits shirk returns the affairs faced by humans to other than Allah. Therefore, return to Allah. Raise your prayers to Allah alone because prayer is a great act of worship, even the brain of worship.
text.107:
Then, in this verse, Allah affirms His oneness in protecting His servants. Only He has the power to remove life's difficulties or harm that befalls His servants, whether the difficulty is due to a lack of wealth or due to impaired health and unfair treatment from others. Every difficulty that befalls a person certainly has a cause. These causes are created by Allah as a test for humans, whether they truly surrender to Allah or not, and they are under His supervision.

Humans, thanks to their long and extensive experience, can know some of these causes. For example, in matters of health, according to human experience, certain bacteria that infect the human body become the cause of certain diseases. Therefore, humans protect themselves from these bacteria, and if they are already contaminated by these bacteria and become sick, they will try to treat their illness until they recover. However, recovery is not a certainty as a result of the treatment, but recovery is only with Allah's permission. Similarly, in other areas of human life, such as social, economic, and political fields. Whenever they experience difficulties, there are certainly causes, and these causes are within their own environment.

The obligation of humans is to seek the cause while praying to Allah with all their heart and placing their trust (tawakal) in Him. After mentioning the difficulties of life that befall humans, Allah also mentions the pleasures and joys that humans experience. Regarding this pleasure and ease of life, Allah states that if He wills with His iradah to bestow blessings upon humans, then no one can hinder it. Happiness and joy are His grace to His servants and according to His iradah. What He wills will surely happen, and Allah is not bound to a cause in giving pleasure and goodness. Allah's grace upon His servants is based on the vastness of His mercy (rahmat).

Allah is the Most Forgiving, forgiving all the sins of those who repent, and the sins of the disbelievers who then believe in Him before death arrives. Allah is the Most Merciful, having mercy on the believers and He does not punish them if they repent from their sins. His forgiveness and compassion encompass all of humanity. Because of His rahmat, not all evil in this world is punished immediately, but He postpones it until a certain time.

Allah says:

"And if Allah were to punish men for that which they earned, He would not leave a moving (living) creature on the surface of the earth, but He gives them respite to an appointed term, and when their term comes, then verily, Allah is Ever All-Seer of His slaves." (Fathir/35: 45)
text.108: Allah commands His Messenger to say to the disbelievers, after the proofs of Allah's oneness and his prophethood have been conveyed to them, that the truth from Allah, namely the Qur'an which forms the basis of Islam, has come before them, revealed to one among themselves. In the Qur'an, there are explanations and descriptions about the messengers of old and their da'wah to their people. However, the Arab polytheists did not know the stories of those messengers, or those stories had been altered or distorted. The Qur'an contains guidelines for human life to attain worldly prosperity and the happiness of the hereafter. So whoever follows those guidelines in his life with full faith, the benefit will return to himself. He will live happily in this world and the hereafter. Likewise, conversely, whoever goes astray, does not use that truth (the Qur'an) as a guide in life, and does not heed the signs of Allah's power in himself and in the universe, then the consequence will be inner misery in this world and in the hereafter. The Prophet Muhammad (saw) is obliged to convey that truth to mankind. The final decision rests with the human being himself, whether he makes the Qur'an a guide in life or turns away from it. He is not God's representative in this world to determine the fate of mankind and has no power to force anyone to benefit or harm. He is only Allah's messenger who conveys the command from the Lord, Rabbul alamin.
text.109:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to steadfastly follow what has been revealed to him, to act according to that revelation, and to teach it to mankind, even if they do not believe in him. The Messenger (peace be upon him) is also asked to be patient in the face of all kinds of disturbances and insults in carrying out the task of conveying and propagating the message. In due time, Allah's judgment will surely come as a punishment against the enemies of the religion, and victory for the Messenger and his followers, in accordance with Allah's promise to the believers. Allah is the Most Just Judge because He decides with righteous reasons. The Messenger (peace be upon him) obeyed these commands and patiently awaited Allah's judgment. These verses are a pleasing promise from Allah to the Messenger and the believers.

The time will come when the Messenger and the believers will achieve victory and the polytheists will experience destruction. Allah will bequeath the world to the Muslims, and they will become rulers of the earth, provided they continue to uphold His religion.
